fluff.name: Barbarian
entries: Primal warriors defined by an unquenchable rage. They use their battle fury to improve reflexes, gain resilience, and perform extraordinary feats of strength.
{@i Choose A or B:} (A) {@item Greataxe}, 4 {@item Handaxe|Handaxes}, {@item Explorer's Pack}, and 15 GP; or (B) 75 GP

classFeature.name: Rage
entries: You can imbue yourself with a primal power called Rage, a force that grants you extraordinary might and resilience. You can enter it as a {@rule Bonus Action} if you aren't wearing Heavy armor.

You can enter your Rage the number of times shown for your Barbarian level in the Rages column of the Barbarian Features table. You regain one expended use when you finish a {@rule Short Rest}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.
While active, your Rage follows the rules below.

entries.name: Damage Resistance
entries: You have {@rule Resistance} to Bludgeoning, Piercing, and Slashing damage.

entries.name: Rage Damage
entries: When you make an attack using Strength—with either a weapon or an {@rule Unarmed Strike}—and deal damage to the target, you gain a bonus to the damage that increases as you gain levels as a Barbarian, as shown in the Rage Damage column of the Barbarian Features table.

entries.name: Strength Advantage
entries: You have {@rule Advantage} on Strength checks and Strength saving throws.

entries.name: No Concentration or Spells
entries: You can't maintain {@status Concentration}, and you can't cast spells.

entries.name: Duration
entries: The Rage lasts until the end of your next turn, and it ends early if you don Heavy armor or have the {@condition Incapacitated} condition. If your Rage is still active on your next turn, you can extend the Rage for another round by doing one of the following:

items: Make an attack roll against an enemy.
Force an enemy to make a saving throw.
Take a {@rule Bonus Action} to extend your Rage.

entries: Each time the Rage is extended, it lasts until the end of your next turn. You can maintain a Rage for up to 10 minutes.

classFeature.name: Unarmored Defense
entries: While you aren't wearing any armor, your base {@rule Armor Class} equals 10 plus your Dexterity and Constitution modifiers. You can use a {@item Shield} and still gain this benefit.

classFeature.name: Weapon Mastery
entries: Your training with weapons allows you to use the mastery properties of two kinds of Simple or Martial Melee of your choice, such as {@item Greataxe|Greataxes} and {@item Handaxe|Handaxes}. Whenever you finish a {@rule Long Rest}, you can practice weapon drills and change one of those weapon choices.
When you reach certain Barbarian levels, you gain the ability to use the mastery properties of more kinds of weapons, as shown in the Weapon Mastery column of the Barbarian Features table.

classFeature.name: Danger Sense
entries: You gain an uncanny sense of when things aren't as they should be, giving you an edge when you dodge perils. You have {@rule Advantage} on Dexterity saving throws unless you have the {@condition Incapacitated} condition.

classFeature.name: Reckless Attack
entries: You can throw aside all concern for defense to attack with increased ferocity. When you make your first attack roll on your turn, you can decide to attack recklessly. Doing so gives you {@rule Advantage} on attack rolls using Strength until the start of your next turn, but attack rolls against you have {@rule Advantage} during that time.

classFeature.name: Barbarian Subclass
entries: You gain a Barbarian subclass of your choice. A subclass is a specialization that grants you features at certain Barbarian levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your subclass's features that are of your Barbarian level or lower.

classFeature.name: Primal Knowledge
entries: You gain proficiency in another skill of your choice from the skill list available to Barbarians at level 1.

In addition, while your Rage is active, you can channel primal power when you attempt certain tasks; whenever you make an ability check using one of the following skills, you can make it as a Strength check even if it normally uses a different ability: {@skill Acrobatics}, {@skill Intimidation}, {@skill Perception}, {@skill Stealth}, or {@skill Survival}. When you use this ability, your Strength represents primal power coursing through you, honing your agility, bearing, and senses.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Barbarian levels 8, 12, and 16.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: You can attack twice instead of once whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn.

classFeature.name: Fast Movement
entries: Your speed increases by 10 feet while you aren't wearing Heavy armor.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Barbarian subclass.

classFeature.name: Feral Instinct
entries: Your instincts are so honed that you have {@rule Advantage} on {@rule Initiative} rolls.

classFeature.name: Instinctive Pounce
entries: As part of the {@rule Bonus Action} you take to enter your Rage, you can move up to half your {@rule Speed}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Brutal Strike
entries: If you use Reckless {@action Attack}, you can forgo any {@rule Advantage} on one Strength-based attack roll of your choice on your turn. The chosen attack roll mustn't have {@rule Disadvantage}. If the chosen attack roll hits, the target takes an extra {@damage 1d10} damage of the same type dealt by the weapon or {@rule Unarmed Strike}, and you can cause one Brutal Strike effect of your choice. You have the following effect options.

entries.name: Forceful Blow
entries: The target is pushed 15 feet straight away from you. You can then move up to half your {@rule Speed} straight toward the target without provoking {@action Opportunity Attack|Opportunity Attacks}.

entries.name: Hamstring Blow
entries: The target's {@rule Speed} is reduced by 15 feet until the start of your next turn. A target can be affected by only one Hamstring Blow at a time—the most recent one.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Barbarian subclass.

classFeature.name: Relentless Rage
entries: Your Rage can keep you fighting despite grievous wounds. If you drop to 0 Hit Points while your Rage is active and don't die outright, you can make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. If you succeed, your Hit Points instead change to a number equal to twice your Barbarian level.
Each time you use this feature after the first, the DC increases by 5. When you finish a Short or Long Rest, the DC resets to 10.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Improved Brutal Strike
entries: You have honed new ways to attack furiously. The following effects are now among your Brutal Strike options.

entries.name: Staggering Blow
entries: The target has {@rule Disadvantage} on the next saving throw it makes, and it can't make {@action Opportunity Attack|Opportunity Attacks} until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Sundering Blow
entries: Before the start of your next turn, the next attack roll made by another creature against the target gains a +5 bonus to the roll. An attack roll can gain only one Sundering Blow bonus.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Barbarian subclass.

classFeature.name: Persistent Rage
entries: When you roll {@rule Initiative}, you can regain all expended uses of Rage. After you regain uses of Rage in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

In addition, your Rage is so fierce that it now lasts for 10 minutes without you needing to do anything to extend it from round to round. Your Rage ends early if you have the {@condition Unconscious} condition (not just the {@condition Incapacitated} condition) or don Heavy armor.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Improved Brutal Strike
entries: The extra damage of your Brutal Strike increases to 2d10. In addition, you can use two different Brutal Strike effects whenever you use your Brutal Strike feature.

classFeature.name: Indomitable Might
entries: If your total for a Strength check or Strength saving throw is less than your Strength score, you can use that score in place of the total.

classFeature.name: Epic Boon
entries: You gain an {@epic-boon Epic Boon} or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify. {@epic-boon Boon of Irresistible Offense} is recommended.

classFeature.name: Primal Champion
entries: You embody primal power. Your Strength and Constitution scores increase by 4, to a maximum of 25.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Berserker
entries: {@i Channel Rage into Violent Fury}

Barbarians who walk the Path of the Berserker direct their Rage primarily toward violence. Their path is one of untrammeled fury, and they thrill in the chaos of battle as they allow their Rage to seize and empower them.

subclassFeature.name: Frenzy
entries: If you use Reckless Attack while your Rage is active, you deal extra damage to the first target you hit on your turn with a Strength-based attack. To determine the extra damage, roll a number of d6s equal to your Rage Damage bonus, and add them together. The damage has the same type as the weapon or {@rule Unarmed Strike} used for the attack.

subclassFeature.name: Mindless Rage
entries: You have {@rule Immunity} to the {@condition Charmed} and {@condition Frightened} conditions while your Rage is active. If you're {@condition Charmed} or {@condition Frightened} when you enter your Rage, the condition ends on you.

subclassFeature.name: Retaliation
entries: When you take damage from a creature that is within 5 feet of you, you can take a {@rule Reaction} to make one melee attack against that creature, using a weapon or an {@rule Unarmed Strike}.

subclassFeature.name: Intimidating Presence
entries: As a {@rule Bonus Action}, you can strike terror into others with your menacing presence and primal power. When you do so, each creature of your choice in a 30-foot {@rule Emanation} originating from you must make a Wisdom saving throw (DC 8 plus your Strength modifier and {@rule Proficiency} Bonus). On a failed save, a creature has the {@condition Frightened} condition for 1 minute. At the end of each of the {@condition Frightened} creature's turns, the creature repeats the save, ending the effect on itself on a success.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest} unless you expend a use of your Rage (no action required) to restore your use of it.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Wild Heart
entries: {@i Walk in Community with the Animal World}

Barbarians who follow the Path of the Wild Heart view themselves as kin to animals. These Barbarians learn magical means to communicate with animals, and their Rage heightens their connection to animals as it fills them with supernatural might.

subclassFeature.name: Animal Speaker
entries: You can cast the {@spell Beast Ally} and {@spell Speak with Nature} spells but only as Rituals. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for them.

subclassFeature.name: Rage of the Wilds
entries: Your Rage taps into the primal power of animals. Whenever you activate your Rage, you gain one of the following options of your choice.

entries.name: Bear
entries: While your Rage is active, you have {@rule Resistance} to every damage type except Force, Necrotic, Psychic, and Radiant.

entries.name: Eagle
entries: When you activate your Rage, you can take the {@action Disengage} and {@action Dash} actions as part of that {@rule Bonus Action}. While your Rage is active, you can take a {@rule Bonus Action} to take both of those actions.

entries.name: Wolf
entries: While your Rage is active, your allies have {@rule Advantage} on attack rolls against any enemy of yours within 5 feet of you.

subclassFeature.name: Aspect of the Wilds
entries: You gain one of the following options of your choice. Whenever you finish a {@rule Long Rest}, you can change your choice.

entries.name: Owl
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision} with a range of 60 feet. If you already have {@sense Darkvision}, its range increases by 60 feet.

entries.name: Panther
entries: You have a {@rule Climb Speed} equal to your {@rule Speed}.

entries.name: Salmon
entries: You have a {@rule Swim Speed} equal to your {@rule Speed}.

subclassFeature.name: Nature Speaker
entries: You can cast the {@spell Commune with Nature} spell but only as a {@rule Ritual}. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for it.

subclassFeature.name: Power of the Wilds
entries: Whenever you activate your Rage, you gain one of the following options of your choice.

entries.name: Falcon
entries: While your Rage is active, you have a {@rule Fly Speed} equal to your {@rule Speed} if you aren't wearing any armor.

entries.name: Lion
entries: While your Rage is active, any of your enemies within 5 feet of you have {@rule Disadvantage} on attack rolls against targets other than you or another Barbarian who has this option active.

entries.name: Ram
entries: While your Rage is active, you can cause a Large or smaller creature to have the {@condition Prone} condition when you hit it with a melee attack.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the World Tree
entries: {@i Trace the Roots and Branches of the Multiverse}

Barbarians who follow the Path of the World Tree connect with the cosmic tree Yggdrasil through their Rage. This tree grows among the Outer Planes, connecting them to each other and the Material Plane. These Barbarians draw on the tree's magic for vitality and as a means of dimensional travel.

subclassFeature.name: Vitality of the Tree
entries: Your Rage taps into the life force of the World Tree. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Vitality Surge
entries: When you activate your Rage, you gain a number of {@rule Temporary Hit Points} equal to your Barbarian level.

entries.name: Life-Giving Force
entries: At the start of each of your turns while your Rage is active, you can choose another creature within 10 feet of yourself to gain {@rule Temporary Hit Points}. To determine the number of {@rule Temporary Hit Points}, roll a number of d6s equal to your Rage Damage bonus, and add them together. If any of these {@rule Temporary Hit Points} remain when your Rage ends, they vanish.

subclassFeature.name: Branches of the Tree
entries: Whenever a creature you can see starts its turn within 30 feet of you while your Rage is active, you can take a {@rule Reaction} to summon spectral branches of the World Tree around it. The target must succeed on a Strength saving throw (DC 8 plus your Strength modifier and {@rule Proficiency} Bonus) or be teleported to an unoccupied space you can see within 5 feet of yourself or in the nearest unoccupied space you can see. After the target teleports, you can reduce its {@rule Speed} to 0 until the end of the current turn.

subclassFeature.name: Battering Roots
entries: During your turn, your reach is 10 feet greater with any Melee weapon that has the Heavy or Versatile property, as tendrils of the World Tree extend from you. When you hit with such a weapon on your turn, you can activate the {@itemMastery Push} or {@itemMastery Topple} mastery property in addition to a different mastery property you're using with that weapon.

subclassFeature.name: Travel Along the Tree
entries: When you activate your Rage and as a {@rule Bonus Action} while your Rage is active, you can teleport up to 60 feet to an unoccupied space you can see.

In addition, once per Rage, you can increase the range of that teleport to 150 feet. When you do so, you can also bring up to six willing creatures who are within 10 feet of you. Each creature teleports to an unoccupied space of your choice within 10 feet of your destination space.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Zealot
entries: {@i Rage in Ecstatic Union with a God}

Barbarians who walk the Path of the Zealot receive boons from a god or pantheon. These Barbarians experience their Rage as an ecstatic episode of divine union that infuses them with power. They are often allies to the priests and other followers of their god or pantheon.

subclassFeature.name: Divine Fury
entries: You can channel divine power into your strikes. On each of your turns while your Rage is active, the first creature you hit with a weapon or an {@rule Unarmed Strike} takes extra damage equal to 1d6 plus half your Barbarian level (round down). The extra damage is Necrotic or Radiant; you choose the type each time you deal the damage.

subclassFeature.name: Warrior of the Gods
entries: A divine entity helps ensure you can continue the fight. You have a pool of four d12s that you can spend to heal yourself. As a {@rule Bonus Action}, you can expend dice from the pool, roll them, and regain a number of Hit Points equal to the roll's total.
Your pool regains all expended dice when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.
The pool's maximum number of dice increases by one when you reach Barbarian levels 6 (5 dice), 12 (6 dice), and 17 (7 dice).

subclassFeature.name: Fanatical Focus
entries: Once per active Rage, if you fail a saving throw, you can reroll it with a bonus equal to your Rage Damage bonus, and you must use the new roll.

subclassFeature.name: Zealous Presence
entries: As a {@rule Bonus Action}, you unleash a battle cry infused with divine energy. Up to ten other creatures of your choice within 60 feet of you gain {@rule Advantage} on attack rolls and saving throws until the start of your next turn.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest} unless you expend a use of your Rage (no action required) to restore your use of it.

subclassFeature.name: Rage of the Gods
entries: When you activate your Rage, you can assume the form of a divine warrior. This form lasts for 1 minute or until you drop to 0 Hit Points. Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.
While in this form, you gain the benefits below.

entries.name: Flight
entries: You have a {@rule Fly Speed} equal to your {@rule Speed} and can hover.

entries.name: Resistance
entries: You have {@rule Resistance} to Necrotic, Psychic, and Radiant damage.

entries.name: Revivification
entries: When a creature within 30 feet of you would drop to 0 Hit Points, you can take a {@rule Reaction} to expend a use of your Rage to instead change the target's Hit Points to a number equal to your Barbarian level.

fluff.name: Bard
entries: Versatile adventurers defined by their use of artistic talents to induce magical effects. They can use powers of music and art to cast spells, inspire allies, and empower their attacks.
{@i Choose A or B:} (A) {@item Leather Armor}, 2 {@item Dagger}, {@item Musical Instrument} of your choice, {@item Entertainer's Pack}, 19 GP; or (B) 90 GP

classFeature.name: Bardic Inspiration
entries: You can supernaturally inspire others through words, music, or dance. This inspiration is represented by your Bardic Inspiration die, which is a d6.

entries.name: Using Bardic Inspiration
entries: As a {@rule Bonus Action}, you can inspire another creature within 60 feet of yourself who can see or hear you. That creature gains one of your Bardic Inspiration dice. A creature can have only one Bardic Inspiration die at a time.

Once within the next hour when the creature fails a {@rule D20 Test}, the creature can roll the Bardic Inspiration die and add the number rolled to the d20, potentially turning the failure into a success. A Bardic Inspiration die is expended when it's rolled.

entries.name: Number of Uses
entries: You can confer a Bardic Inspiration die a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

entries.name: At Higher Levels
entries: Your Bardic Inspiration die changes when you reach certain Bard levels, as shown in the Bardic Die column of the Bard Features table. The die becomes a d8 at level 5, a d10 at level 10, and a d12 at level 15.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: You have learned to cast spells through your bardic arts. The information below details how you use those rules with Bard spells, which appear in the {@spells ?spell-class-filter=bard|Bard spell list}.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You know two cantrips of your choice from the Bard spell list. {@spell Minor Illusion} and {@spell Vicious Mockery} are recommended.
Whenever you gain a Bard level, you can replace one of your cantrips with another cantrip of your choice from the Bard spell list.
When you reach Bard levels 4 and 10, you learn another cantrip of your choice from the Bard spell list, as shown in the Cantrips column of the Bard Features table.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Bard Features table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your level 1+ spells. You regain all expended slots when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

entries.name: Prepared Spells of Level 1+
entries: You prepare the list of level 1+ spells that are available for you to cast with this feature. To start, choose four level 1 spells from the Bard spell list. {@spell Fearie Fire}, {@spell Hideous Laughter}, {@spell Dissonant Whispers}, and {@spell Healing Word} are recommended.

The number of spells on your list increases as you gain Bard levels, as shown in the Spells column of the Bard Features table. Whenever that number increases, choose additional spells from the Bard spell list until the number of spells on your list matches the number on the table. The chosen spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For example, if you're a level 3 Bard, your list of prepared spells can include six spells of levels 1 and 2 in any combination.

If another Bard feature gives you spells that you always have prepared, those spells don't count against the number of spells you can prepare with this feature, but those spells otherwise count as Bard spells for you.

entries.name: Changing Your Prepared Spells
entries: Whenever you gain a Bard level, you can replace one spell on your list with another Bard spell for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your Bard spells.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use a {@item Musical Instrument} as a {@rule Spellcasting Focus} for your Bard spells.

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: You gain {@rule Expertise} in two of your skill proficiencies of your choice. {@skill Performance} and {@skill Persuasion} are recommended if you have proficiency in them.
At Bard level 9, you gain {@rule Expertise} in two more of your skill proficiencies of your choice.

classFeature.name: Jack of All Trades
entries: You can add half your {@rule Proficiency} Bonus (round down) to any ability check you make that uses a skill proficiency you lack and that doesn't otherwise use your {@rule Proficiency} Bonus.
For example, if you make a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check and lack {@skill Athletics} proficiency, you can add half your {@rule Proficiency} Bonus to the check.

entries.name: A Bard's Repertoire
entries: Does your Bard beat a {@item drum} while chanting the deeds of ancient heroes? Strum a {@item lute} while crooning romantic tunes? Perform arias of stirring power? Recite dramatic monologues from classic tragedies? Use the rhythm of a folk dance to coordinate the movement of allies in battle? Compose naughty limericks?

When you play a Bard, consider the style of artistic performance you favor, the moods you might invoke, and the themes that inspire your own creations. Are your poems inspired by moments of natural beauty, or are they brooding reflections on loss? Do you prefer lofty hymns or rowdy tavern songs? Are you drawn to laments for the fallen or celebrations of joy? Do you dance merry jigs or perform elaborate interpretive choreography? Do you focus on one style of performance or strive to master them all?

classFeature.name: Bard Subclass
entries: You gain a Bard subclass of your choice. A subclass is a specialization that grants you features at certain Bard levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your subclass's features that are of your Bard level or lower.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Bard levels 8, 12, and 16.

classFeature.name: Font of Inspiration
entries: You now regain all your expended uses of Bardic Inspiration when you finish a Short or Long Rest.
In addition, you can expend a spell slot (no action required) to regain one expended use of Bardic Inspiration.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Bard Subclass.

classFeature.name: Countercharm
entries: You can use musical notes or words of power to disrupt mind-influencing effects. If you or a creature within 30 feet of you fails a saving throw against an effect that applies the {@condition Charmed} or {@condition Frightened} condition, you can take a {@rule Reaction} to cause the save to be rerolled, and the new roll has {@rule Advantage}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: You gain {@rule Expertise} in two of your Skill Proficiencies of your choice.

classFeature.name: Magical Secrets
entries: You've learned secrets from various magical traditions. Whenever you reach a Bard level (including this level) and the Prepared Spells number in the Bard Features table increases, you can choose any of your new prepared spells from the Bard, Cleric, Druid, and Wizard spell lists, and the chosen spells count as Bard spells for you (see a class's section for its spell list). In addition, whenever you replace a spell prepared for this class, you can replace it with a spell from those lists.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Bard Subclass.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Superior Inspiration
entries: When you roll {@rule Initiative}, you regain expended uses of Bardic Inspiration until you have two if you have fewer than that.

classFeature.name: Epic Boon
entries: You gain an {@epic-boon Epic Boon} or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify. {@epic-boon Boon of Spell Recall} is recommended.

classFeature.name: Words of Creation
entries: You have mastered two of the Words of Creation: the words of life and death. You therefore always have the {@spell Power Word Heal} and {@spell Power Word Kill} spells prepared. When you cast either spell, you can target a second creature with it if that creature is within 10 feet of the first target.

subclassFeature.name: College of Dance
entries: {@i Move in Harmony with the Cosmos}

Bards of the College of Dance know that the Words of Creation can't be contained within speech or song; the words are uttered by the movements of celestial bodies and flow through the motions of the smallest creatures. These Bards practice a way of being in harmony with the whirling cosmos that emphasizes agility, speed, and grace.

subclassFeature.name: Dazzling Footwork
entries: While you aren't wearing armor or wielding a {@item Shield}, you gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Dance Virtuoso
entries: You have {@rule Advantage} on any Charisma ({@skill Performance}) check you make that involves you dancing.

entries.name: Unarmored Defense
entries: Your base {@rule Armor Class} equals 10 plus your Dexterity and Charisma modifiers.

entries.name: Agile Strikes
entries: When you expend a use of your Bardic Inspiration as part of an action, a {@rule Bonus Action}, or a {@rule Reaction}, you can make one {@rule Unarmed Strike} as part of that action, {@rule Bonus Action}, or {@rule Reaction}.

entries.name: Bardic Damage
entries: You can use Dexterity instead of Strength for the attack rolls of your Unarmed Strikes. When you deal damage with an {@rule Unarmed Strike}, you can deal Bludgeoning damage equal to a roll of your Bardic Inspiration die plus your Dexterity modifier, instead of the strike's normal damage. This roll doesn't expend the die.

subclassFeature.name: Inspiring Movement
entries: When an enemy you can see ends its turn within 5 feet of you, you can take a {@rule Reaction} and expend one use of your Bardic Inspiration to move up to half your {@rule Speed}. Then one ally of your choice within 30 feet of you can also move up to half their {@rule Speed} using their {@rule Reaction}.
None of this feature's movement provokes {@action Opportunity Attack|Opportunity Attacks}.

subclassFeature.name: Tandem Footwork
entries: When you roll {@rule Initiative}, you can expend one use of your Bardic Inspiration if you don't have the {@condition Incapacitated} condition. When you do so, roll your Bardic Inspiration die; you and each ally within 30 feet of you who can see or hear you gains a bonus to {@rule Initiative} equal to the number rolled.

subclassFeature.name: Leading Evasion
entries: When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw and only half damage if you fail. If any creatures within 5 feet of you are making the same Dexterity saving throw, you can share this benefit with them for that save.
You can't use this feature if you have the {@condition Incapacitated} condition.

subclassFeature.name: College of Glamour
entries: {@i Weave Beguiling Fey Magic}

The College of Glamour traces its origins to the beguiling magic of the Feywild. Bards who study this magic weave threads of beauty and terror into their songs and stories, and the mightiest among them can cloak themselves in otherworldly majesty. Their performances stir up wistful longing for forgotten innocence, evoke unconscious memories of long-held fears, and tug at the emotions of even the most hard-hearted listeners.

subclassFeature.name: Beguiling Magic
entries: You always have the {@spell Charm Person} and {@spell Mirror Image} spells prepared.

In addition, immediately after you cast an Enchantment or Illusion spell using a spell slot, you can cause a creature you can see within 60 feet of yourself to make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the target has the {@condition Charmed} or {@condition Frightened} condition (your choice) for 1 minute. The target repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.
Once you use this benefit, you can't use it again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest}. You can also restore your use of it by expending one use of your Bardic Inspiration (no action required).

subclassFeature.name: Mantle of Inspiration
entries: You can weave fey magic into a song or dance to fill others with vigor. As a {@rule Bonus Action}, you can expend a use of Bardic Inspiration, rolling a Bardic Inspiration die. When you do so, choose a number of other creatures within 60 feet of yourself, up to a number equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of one creature). Each of those creatures gains a number of {@rule Temporary Hit Points} equal to two times the number rolled on the Bardic Inspiration die, and then each can use its {@rule Reaction} to move up to its {@rule Speed} without provoking {@action Opportunity Attack|Opportunity Attacks}.

subclassFeature.name: Mantle of Majesty
entries: You always have the {@spell Command} spell prepared.

As a {@rule Bonus Action}, you cast {@spell Command} without expending a spell slot, and you take on an unearthly appearance for 1 minute or until your {@status Concentration} ends. During this time, you can cast {@spell Command} as a {@rule Bonus Action} without expending a spell slot.
Any creature {@condition Charmed} by you automatically fails its saving throw against the {@spell Command} you cast with this feature.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest}. You can also restore your use of it by expending a level 3+ spell slot (no action required).

subclassFeature.name: Unbreakable Majesty
entries: As a {@rule Bonus Action}, you can assume a magically majestic presence for 1 minute or until you have the {@condition Incapacitated} condition. For the duration, whenever any creature hits you with an attack roll for the first time on a turn, the attacker must succeed on a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC, or the attack misses instead, as the creature recoils from your majesty.
Once you assume this majestic presence, you can't do so again until you finish a Short of Long Rest.

subclassFeature.name: College of Lore
entries: {@i Plumb the Depths of Magical Knowledge}

Bards of the College of Lore collect spells and secrets from diverse sources, such as scholarly tomes, mystical rites, and peasant tales. The college's members gather in libraries and universities to share their lore with one another. They also meet at festivals or affairs of state, where they can expose corruption, unravel lies, and poke fun at self-important figures of authority.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: You gain proficiency with three skills of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Cutting Words
entries: You learn to use your wit to supernaturally distract, confuse, and otherwise sap the confidence and competence of others. When a creature that you can see within 60 feet of yourself makes a damage roll or succeeds on an ability check or attack roll, you can take a {@rule Reaction} to expend one use of your Bardic Inspiration; roll your Bardic Inspiration die, and subtract the number rolled from the creature's roll, reducing the damage or potentially turning the success into a failure.

subclassFeature.name: Magical Discoveries
entries: You learn two spells of your choice. These spells can come from the Cleric, Druid, or Wizard spell list or any combination thereof. A spell you choose must be a cantrip or a spell for which you have spell slots, as shown in the Bard Features table.
You always have the chosen spells prepared, and whenever you gain a Bard level, you can replace one of the spells with another spell that meets these requirements.

subclassFeature.name: Peerless Skill
entries: When you make an ability check or attack roll and fail, you can expend one use of Bardic Inspiration; roll the Bardic Inspiration die, and add the number rolled to the d20, potentially turning a failure into a success. On a failure, the Bardic Inspiration isn't expended.

subclassFeature.name: College of Valor
entries: {@i Sing the Deeds of Ancient Heroes}

Bards of the College of Valor are daring storytellers whose tales preserve the memory of the great heroes of the past. These Bards sing the deeds of the mighty in vaulted halls or to crowds gathered around great bonfires. They travel to witness great events firsthand and to ensure that the memory of these events doesn't pass away. With their songs, they inspire new generations to reach the same heights of accomplishment as the heroes of old.

subclassFeature.name: Combat Inspiration
entries: You can use your wit to turn the tide of battle. A creature that has a Bardic Inspiration die from you can use it for one of the following effects.

entries.name: Defense
entries: When the creature is hit by an attack roll, that creature can use its {@rule Reaction} to roll the Bardic Inspiration die and add the number rolled to its AC against that attack, potentially causing the attack to miss.

entries.name: Offense
entries: Immediately after the creature hits a target with an attack roll, the creature can roll the Bardic Inspiration die and add the number rolled to the attack's damage against the target.

subclassFeature.name: Martial Training
entries: You gain proficiency with Martial weapons and training with Medium armor and Shields.
In addition, you can use a Simple or Martial weapon as a {@rule Spellcasting Focus} to cast spells from your Bard spell list.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: You can attack twice instead of once whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn.
In addition, you can cast one of your can trips that has a casting time of an action in place of one of those attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Battle Magic
entries: After you cast a spell that has a casting time of an action, you can make one attack with a weapon as a {@rule Bonus Action}.

fluff.name: Cleric
entries: Divine casters defined by their powerful spells and devotion to a deity. Clerics use the power of their god to help allies and destroy foes.
{@i Choose A or B:} (A) {@item Chain Shirt}, {@item Shield}, {@item Mace}, {@item Holy Symbol}, {@item Priest's Pack}, 7 GP; or (B) 90 GP

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: You have learned to cast spells through prayer and meditation. The information below details how you use those rules with Cleric spells, which appear on the {@spells ?spell-class-filter=cleric|Cleric spell list}.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You know three cantrips of your choice from the Cleric spell list. {@spell Guidance}, {@spell Sacred Flame}, and {@spell Thaumaturgy} are recommended.
Whenever you gain a Cleric level, you can replace one of your cantrips with another cantrip of your choice from the Cleric spell list.
When you reach Cleric levels 4 and 10, you learn another cantrip of your choice from the Cleric spell list, as shown in the Cantrips column of the Cleric Features table.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Cleric Features table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your level 1+ spells. You regain all expended slots when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

entries.name: Prepared Spells of Level 1+
entries: You prepare the list of level 1+ spells that are available for you to cast with this feature. To start, choose four level 1 spells from the Cleric spell list. {@spell Bless}, {@spell Healing Word}, {@spell Guiding Bolt}, and {@spell Command} are recommended.

The number of spells on your list increases as you gain Cleric levels, as shown in the Spells column of the Cleric Features table. Whenever that number increases, choose additional spells from the Cleric spell list until the number of spells on your list matches the number on the table. The chosen spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For example, if you're a level 3 Cleric, your list of prepared spells can include six spells of levels 1 and 2 in any combination.

If another Cleric feature gives you spells that you always have prepared, those spells don't count against the number of spells you can prepare with this feature, but those spells otherwise count as Cleric spells for you.

entries.name: Changing Your Prepared Spells
entries: Whenever you finish a {@rule Long Rest}, you can change your list of prepared spells, replacing any of the spells there with other Cleric spells for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your Cleric spells.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use a {@item Holy Symbol} as a {@rule Spellcasting Focus} for your Cleric spells.

classFeature.name: Divine Order
entries: You have dedicated yourself to one of the following sacred roles of your choice.

entries.name: Protector
entries: Trained for battle, you gain proficiency with Martial weapons and training with Heavy armor.

entries.name: Thaumaturge
entries: You know one extra cantrip from the Cleric spell list. In addition, your mystical connection to the divine gives you a bonus to your Intelligence ({@skill Arcana} or {@skill Religion}) checks. The bonus equals your Wisdom modifier (minimum of +1).

classFeature.name: Channel Divinity
entries: You can channel divine energy directly from the Outer Planes to fuel magical effects. You start with two such effects: Divine Spark and Turn Undead, each of which is described below. Each time you use this class's Channel Divinity, choose which Channel Divinity effect from this class to create. You gain additional effect options at higher Cleric levels.

You can use this class's Channel Divinity twice. You regain one of its expended uses when you finish a {@rule Short Rest}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}. You gain additional uses when you reach certain Cleric levels, as shown in the Channel Divinity column of the Cleric Features table.
If a Channel Divinity effect requires a saving throw, the DC equals the spell save DC from this class's Spellcasting feature.

classFeature.name: Divine Spark
entries: As a {@action Magic} action, you point your {@item Holy Symbol} at another creature you can see within 30 feet of yourself and focus divine energy at it. Roll 1d8 and add your Wisdom modifier. You either restore Hit Points to the creature equal to that total or force the creature to make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes Necrotic or Radiant damage (your choice) equal to that total. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage (round down).
You roll an additional d8 when you reach Cleric levels 7 (2d8), 13 (3d8), and 18 (4d8).

classFeature.name: Turn Undead
entries: As a {@action Magic} action, you present your {@item Holy Symbol} and censure Undead creatures. Each Undead of your choice within 30 feet of you must make a Wisdom saving throw. If the creature fails its save, it has the {@condition Frightened} and {@condition Incapacitated} conditions for 1 minute. For that duration, it tries to move as far from you as it can on its turns. This effect ends early on the creature if it takes any damage, if you have the {@condition Incapacitated} condition, or if you die.

classFeature.name: Cleric Subclass
entries: You gain a Cleric subclass of your choice. A subclass is a specialization that grants you features at certain Cleric levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your subclass's features that are of your Cleric level or lower.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Cleric levels 8, 12, and 16.

classFeature.name: Sear Undead
entries: Whenever you use Turn Undead, you can roll a number of d8s equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1d8) and add the rolls together. Each Undead that fails its saving throw against that use of Turn Undead takes Radiant damage equal to the roll's total. This damage doesn't end the turn effect.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Cleric Subclass.

classFeature.name: Blessed Strikes
entries: Divine power infuses you in battle. You gain one of the following options of your choice (if you get either option from a Cleric subclass in an older book, use only the option you choose for this feature).

entries.name: Divine Strike
entries: Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with an attack roll using a weapon, you can cause the target to take an extra {@damage 1d8} Necrotic or Radiant damage (your choice).

entries.name: Potent Spellcasting
entries: Add your Wisdom modifier to the damage you deal with any Cleric cantrip.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Divine Intervention
entries: You can call on your deity or pantheon to intervene on your behalf. As a {@action Magic} action, choose any Cleric spell of level 5 or lower that doesn't require a {@rule Reaction} to cast. As part of the same action, you cast that spell without expending a spell slot or needing Material components. You can't use this feature again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Improved Blessed Strikes
entries: The option you chose for Blessed Strikes grows more powerful.

entries.name: Divine Strike
entries: The extra damage of your Divine Strike increases to 2d8.

entries.name: Potent Spellcasting
entries: When you cast a Cleric cantrip and deal damage to a creature with it, you can give vitality to yourself or another creature within 60 feet of yourself, granting a number of {@rule Temporary Hit Points} equal to twice your Wisdom modifier.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Cleric Subclass.

classFeature.name: Epic Boon
entries: You gain an {@epic-boon Epic Boon} or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify. {@epic-boon Boon of Fate} is recommended.

classFeature.name: Greater Divine Intervention
entries: You can call on even more powerful divine intervention. When you use your Divine Intervention feature, you can choose {@spell Wish} when you select a spell. If you do so, you can't use Divine Intervention again until you finish 2d4 Long Rests.

subclassFeature.name: Life Domain
entries: {@i Soothe the Hurts of the World}
The Life Domain focuses on the positive energy that helps sustain all life in the multiverse. Clerics who tap into this domain are masters of healing, using that life force to cure many hurts.

Existence itself relies on the positive energy associated with this domain, so a Cleric of almost any religious tradition might choose it. This domain is particularly associated with agricultural deities, gods of healing or endurance, and gods of home and community. Religious orders of healing also seek the magic of this domain.

subclassFeature.name: Disciple of Life
entries: When a spell you cast with a spell slot restores Hit Points to a creature, that creature regains additional Hit Points on the turn you cast the spell. The additional Hit Points equal 2 plus the spell slot's level.

subclassFeature.name: Life Domain Spells
entries: Your connection to this divine domain ensures you always have certain spells ready. When you reach a Cleric level specified in the Life Domain Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Life Domain Spells
rows: {@spell Aid}, {@spell Bless}, {@spell Cure Wounds}, {@spell Lesser Restoration}

subclassFeature.name: Preserve Life
entries: As a {@action Magic} action, you present your {@item Holy Symbol} and expend a use of your Channel Divinity to evoke healing energy that can restore a number of Hit Points equal to five times your Cleric level. Choose {@rule Bloodied} creatures within 30 feet of yourself (which can include you), and divide those Hit Points among them. This feature can restore a creature to no more than half its {@rule Hit Points|Hit Point} maximum.

subclassFeature.name: Blessed Healer
entries: The healing spells you cast on others heal you as well. Immediately after you cast a spell with a spell slot that restores Hit Points to one creature other than you, you regain Hit Points equal to 2 plus the spell slot's level.

subclassFeature.name: Supreme Healing
entries: When you would normally roll one or more dice to restore Hit Points to a creature with a spell or Channel Divinity, don't roll those dice for the healing; instead use the highest number possible for each die. For example, instead of restoring 2d6 Hit Points to a creature with a spell, you restore 12.

subclassFeature.name: Light Domain
entries: {@i Bring Light to Banish Darkness}

The Light Domain emphasizes the divine power to bring about blazing fire and revelation. Clerics who wield this power are enlightened souls infused with radiance and the power of their deities' discerning vision, charged with chasing away lies and burning away darkness.

The Light Domain is associated with gods of truth, vigilance, beauty, insight, and renewal. Some of these gods are identified with the sun or as charioteers who guide the sun across the sky. Others are sentinels who pierce deception. Some are deities of beauty and artistry who teach that art is a vehicle for the soul's improvement.

subclassFeature.name: Light Domain Spells
entries: Your connection to this divine domain ensures you always have certain spells ready. When you reach a Cleric level specified in the Light Domain Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Light Domain Spells
rows: {@spell Burning Hands}, {@spell Faerie Fire}, {@spell Scorching Ray}, {@spell See Invisibility}

subclassFeature.name: Radiance of the Dawn
entries: As a {@action Magic} action, you present your {@item Holy Symbol} and expend a use of your Channel Divinity to emit a flash of light in a 30-foot {@rule Emanation} originating from yourself. Any magical {@rule Darkness}—such as that created by the {@spell Darkness} spell—in that area is dispelled. Additionally, each creature of your choice in that area must make a Constitution saving throw, taking Radiant damage equal to 2d10 plus your Cleric level on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.

subclassFeature.name: Warding Flare
entries: When a creature that you can see within 30 feet of yourself makes an attack roll, you can take a {@rule Reaction} to impose {@rule Disadvantage} on the attack roll, causing light to flare before it hits or misses.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Warding Flare
entries: You regain all expended uses of your Warding Flare when you finish a Short or Long Rest.
In addition, whenever you use Warding Flare, you can give the target of the triggering attack a number of {@rule Temporary Hit Points} equal to 2d6 plus your Wisdom modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Corona of Light
entries: As a {@action Magic} action, you cause yourself to emit an aura of sunlight that lasts for 1 minute or until you dismiss it (no action required). You emit {@rule Bright Light} in a 60-foot radius and {@rule Dim Light} for an additional 30 feet. Your enemies in the {@rule Bright Light} have {@rule Disadvantage} on saving throws against your Radiance of the Dawn and any spell that deals Fire or Radiant damage.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Trickery Domain
entries: {@i Make Mischief and Challenge Authority}

The Trickery Domain offers magic of deception, illusion, and stealth. Clerics who wield this magic are a disruptive force in the world, puncturing pride, mocking tyrants, freeing captives, and flouting hollow traditions. They prefer subterfuge and pranks to direct confrontation.

Gods of trickery are mischief-makers and instigators who stand as a constant challenge to the accepted order among both gods and mortals. They embody the forces of change and social upheaval, and they're patrons of thieves, scoundrels, gamblers, rebels, and liberators. Religious orders that operate in secret, especially those that seek to undermine oppressive governments or hierarchies, also draw on the power of the Trickery Domain.

subclassFeature.name: Blessing of the Trickster
entries: As a {@action Magic} action, you can choose yourself or a willing creature within 30 feet of yourself to have {@rule Advantage} on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks. This blessing lasts until you finish a {@rule Long Rest} or you use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Domain Spells
entries: Your connection to this divine domain ensures you always have certain spells ready. When you reach a Cleric level specified in the Trickery Domain Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Trickery Domain Spells
rows: {@spell Charm Person}, {@spell Disguise Self}, {@spell Invisibility}, {@spell Pass without Trace}

subclassFeature.name: Invoke Duplicity
entries: As a {@rule Bonus Action}, you can expend one use of your Channel Divinity to create a perfect visual illusion of yourself in an unoccupied space you can see within 30 feet of yourself. The illusion is intangible and doesn't occupy its space. It lasts for 1 minute, but it ends early if you dismiss it (no action required) or have the {@condition Incapacitated} condition. The illusion is animated and mimics your expressions and gestures. While it persists, you gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Cast Spells
entries: You can cast spells as though you were in the illusion's space, but you must use your own senses.

entries.name: Distract
entries: When both you and your illusion are within 5 feet of a creature that can see the illusion, you have {@rule Advantage} on attack rolls against that creature, given how distracting the illusion is to the target.

entries.name: Move
entries: As a {@rule Bonus Action}, you can move the illusion up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space you can see that is within 120 feet of yourself.

subclassFeature.name: Trickster's Transposition
entries: Whenever you take the {@rule Bonus Action} to create or move the illusion of your Invoke Duplicity, you can teleport, swapping places with the illusion.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Duplicity
entries: The illusion of your Invoke Duplicity has grown more powerful in the following ways.

entries.name: Shared Distraction
entries: When you and your allies make attack rolls against a creature within 5 feet of the illusion, the attack rolls have {@rule Advantage}.

entries.name: Healing Illusion
entries: When the illusion ends, you or a creature of your choice within 5 feet of it regains a number of Hit Points equal to your Cleric level.

subclassFeature.name: War Domain
entries: {@i Inspire Valor and Smite Foes}

War has many manifestations. It can make heroes of ordinary people. It can be desperate and horrific, with acts of cruelty and cowardice eclipsing instances of excellence and courage. Clerics who tap into the magic of the War Domain excel in battle, inspiring others to fight the good fight or offering acts of violence as prayers.

Gods of the War Domain watch over warriors and reward them for their great deeds. They include champions of honor and chivalry as well as gods of destruction and pillage. Other war gods take a more neutral stance, promoting war in all its manifestations and supporting warriors in any circumstance.

subclassFeature.name: Domain Spells
entries: Your connection to this divine domain ensures you always have certain spells ready. When you reach a Cleric level specified in the War Domain Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: War Domain Spells
rows: {@spell Guiding Bolt}, {@spell Magic Weapon}, {@spell Shield of Faith}, {@spell Spiritual Weapon}

subclassFeature.name: Guided Strike
entries: When you or a creature within 30 feet of you misses with an attack roll, you can expend one use of your Channel Divinity and give that roll a +10 bonus, potentially causing it to hit. When you use this feature to benefit another creature's attack roll, you must take a {@rule Reaction} to do so.

subclassFeature.name: War Priest
entries: As a {@rule Bonus Action}, you can make one attack with a weapon or an {@rule Unarmed Strike}. You can use this {@rule Bonus Action} a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a Short or Long Rest.

subclassFeature.name: War God's Blessing
entries: You can expend a use of your Channel Divinity to cast {@spell Shield of Faith} or {@spell Spiritual Weapon} rather than expending a spell slot. When you cast either spell in this way, the spell doesn't require {@status Concentration}. Instead the spell lasts for 1 minute, but it ends early if you cast that spell again, have the {@condition Incapacitated} condition, or die.

subclassFeature.name: Avatar of Battle
entries: You gain {@rule Resistance} to Bludgeoning, Piercing, and Slashing damage.

fluff.name: Druid
entries: Primal casters defined by their strong connection to nature and wildlife. They can use powers of the natural world to cast spells, summon allies, and even transform themselves in beasts.
{@i Choose A or B:} (A) {@item Leather Armor}, {@item Shield}, {@item Sickle}, {@item Druidic Focus|Druidic Focus (Quarterstaff)}, {@item Explorer's Pack}, {@item Herbalism kit}, 9 GP; or (B) 50 GP

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: You have learned to cast spells through studying the mystical forces of nature. The information below details how you use those rules with Druid spells, which appear on the {@spells ?spell-class-filter=druid|Druid spell list}.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You know two cantrips of your choice from the Druid spell list. {@spell Druidcraft} and {@spell Starry Wisp} are recommended.
Whenever you gain a Druid level, you can replace one of your cantrips with another cantrip of your choice from the Druid spell list.
When you reach Druid levels 4 and 10, you learn another cantrip of your choice from the Druid spell list, as shown in the Cantrips column of the Druid Features table.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Druid Features table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your level 1+ spells. You regain all expended slots when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

entries.name: Prepared Spells of Level 1+
entries: You prepare the list of level 1+ spells that are available for you to cast with this feature. To start, choose four level 1 spells from the Druid spell list. {@spell Entangle}, {@spell Goodberry}, {@spell Faerie Fire}, and {@spell Thunderwave} are recommended.

The number of spells on your list increases as you gain Druid levels, as shown in the Spells column of the Druid Features table. Whenever that number increases, choose additional spells from the Druid spell list until the number of spells on your list matches the number on the table. The chosen spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For example, if you're a level 3 Druid, your list of prepared spells can include six spells of levels 1 and 2 in any combination.

If another Druid feature gives you spells that you always have prepared, those spells don't count against the number of spells you can prepare with this feature, but those spells otherwise count as Druid spells for you.

entries.name: Changing Your Prepared Spells
entries: Whenever you finish a {@rule Long Rest}, you can change your list of prepared spells, replacing any of the spells with other Druid spells for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your Druid spells.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use a {@item Druidic Focus} as a {@rule Spellcasting Focus} for your Druid spells.

classFeature.name: Primal Order
entries: You have dedicated yourself to one of the following sacred roles of your choice.

entries.name: Magician
entries: You know one extra cantrip from the Druid spell list. In addition, your mystical connection to nature gives you a bonus to your Intelligence ({@skill Arcana} or {@skill Nature}) checks. The bonus equals your Wisdom modifier (minimum bonus of +1).

entries.name: Warden
entries: Trained for battle, you gain proficiency with Martial weapons and training with Medium armor.

classFeature.name: Druidic
entries: You know Druidic, the secret language of Druids. While learning this ancient tongue, you also unlocked the magic of communicating with animals; you always have the {@spell Speak with Nature} spell prepared.

You can use Druidic to leave hidden messages. You and others who know Druidic automatically spot such a message. Others spot the message's presence with a successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check but can't decipher it without magic.

classFeature.name: Wild Companion
entries: You can summon a nature spirit that assumes an animal form to aid you. As a {@action Magic} action, you can expend a spell slot or a use of Wild Shape to cast the {@spell Find Familiar} spell without Material components.
When you cast the spell in this way, the familiar is Fey and disappears when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

classFeature.name: Wild Shape
entries: The power of nature allows you to assume the form of an animal. As a {@rule Bonus Action}, you shape-shift into a Beast form that you have learned for this feature (see "Known Forms" below). You stay in that form for a number of hours equal to half your Druid level or until you use Wild Shape again, have the {@condition Incapacitated} condition, or die. You can also leave the form early as a {@rule Bonus Action}.

entries.name: Number of Uses
entries: You can use Wild Shape twice. You regain one expended use when you finish a {@rule Short Rest}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.
You gain additional uses when you reach certain Druid levels, as shown in the Wild Shape column of the Druid Features table.

entries.name: Known Forms
entries: You know four Beast forms for this feature, chosen from among Beast stat blocks that have a maximum {@rule Challenge Rating} of 1/4 and that lack a {@rule Fly Speed} (see appendix B for stat block options). The {@creature Rat}, {@creature Riding Horse}, {@creature Spider}, and {@creature Wolf} are recommended. Whenever you finish a {@rule Long Rest}, you can replace one of your known forms with another eligible form.

When you reach certain Druid levels, your number of known forms and the maximum {@rule Challenge Rating} for those forms increases, as shown in the Beast Shapes table. In addition, starting at level 8, you can adopt a form that has a {@rule Fly Speed}.
When choosing known forms, you may look in the Monster Manual or elsewhere for eligible Beasts if the Dungeon Master permits you to do so.

entries.name: Rules While Transformed
entries: While in a form, you retain your personality, memories, and ability to speak, and the following rules apply:

items.name: Temporary Hit Points
entries: When you assume a Wild Shape form, you gain a number of {@rule Temporary Hit Points} equal to your Druid level.

items.name: Game Statistics
entries: Your game statistics are replaced by the Beast's stat block, but you retain your creature type; Hit Points; {@rule Hit Point Dice}; Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores; class features; languages; and feats. You also retain your skill and saving throw proficiencies and use your {@rule Proficiency} Bonus for them, in addition to gaining the proficiencies of the creature. If a skill or saving throw modifier in the Beast's stat block is higher than yours, use the one in the stat block.

items.name: No Spellcasting
entries: You can't cast spells, but shape-shifting doesn't break your {@status Concentration} or otherwise interfere with a spell you've already cast.

items.name: Objects
entries: Your ability to handle objects is determined by the form's limbs rather than your own. In addition, you choose whether your equipment falls in your space, merges into your new form, or is worn by it. Worn equipment functions as normal, but the DM decides whether it's practical for the new form to wear a piece of equipment based on the creature's size and shape. Your equipment doesn't change size or shape to match the new form, and any equipment that the new form can't wear must either fall to the ground or merge with the form. Equipment that merges with the form has no effect while you're in that form.

classFeature.name: Druid Subclass
entries: You gain a Druid subclass of your choice. A subclass is a specialization that grants you features at certain Druid levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your subclass's features that are of your Druid level or lower.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Druid levels 8, 12, and 16.

classFeature.name: Wild Resurgence
entries: Once on each of your turns, if you have no uses of Wild Shape left, you can give yourself one use by expending a spell slot (no action required).
In addition, you can expend one use of Wild Shape (no action required) to give yourself a level 1 spell slot, but you can't do so again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Druid Subclass.

classFeature.name: Elemental Fury
entries: The might of the elements flows through you. You gain one of the following options of your choice.

entries.name: Potent Spellcasting
entries: Add your Wisdom modifier to the damage you deal with any Druid cantrip.

entries.name: Primal Strike
entries: Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with an attack roll using a weapon or a Beast form's attack in Wild Shape, you can cause the target to take an extra {@damage 1d8} Cold, Fire, Lightning, or Thunder damage (choose when you hit).

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} Feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Druid Subclass.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} Feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Druid Subclass.

classFeature.name: Improved Elemental Fury
entries: The option you chose for Elemental Fury grows more powerful, as detailed below.

entries.name: Potent Spellcasting
entries: When you cast a Druid cantrip with a range of 10 feet or greater, the spell's range increases by 300 feet.

entries.name: Primal Strike
entries: The extra damage of your Primal Strike increases to 2d8.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} Feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Beast Spells
entries: While using Wild Shape, you can cast spells in Beast form, except for any spell that has a Material component with a cost specified or that consumes its Material component.

classFeature.name: Epic Boon
entries: You gain an {@epic-boon Epic Boon} or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify. {@epic-boon Boon of Dimensional Travel} is recommended.

classFeature.name: Archdruid
entries: The vitality of nature constantly blooms within you, granting you the following benefits.

entries.name: Evergreen Wild Shape
entries: Whenever you roll {@rule Initiative} and have no uses of Wild Shape left, you regain one expended use of it.

entries.name: Nature Magician
entries: You can convert uses of Wild Shape into a spell slot (no action required). Choose a number of your unexpended uses of Wild Shape and convert them into a single spell slot, with each use contributing 2 spell levels. For example, if you convert two uses of Wild Shape, you produce a level 4 spell slot. Once you use this benefit, you can't do so again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

entries.name: Longevity
entries: The primal magic that you wield causes you to age more slowly. For every ten years that pass, your body ages only one year.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Land
entries: {@i Celebrate Connection to the Natural World}

The Circle of the Land comprises mystics and sages who safeguard ancient knowledge and rites. These Druids meet within sacred circles of trees or standing stones to whisper primal secrets in Druidic. The circle's wisest members preside as the chief priests of their communities.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Land Spells
entries: Whenever you finish a {@rule Long Rest}, choose one type of land: arid, polar, temperate, or tropical. Consult the table below that corresponds to the chosen type; you have the spells listed for your Druid level and lower prepared.

entries.caption: Polar Land
rows: {@spell Fog Cloud}, {@spell Hold Person}, {@spell Ray of Frost}

entries.caption: Tropical Land
rows: {@spell Acid Splash}, {@spell Ray of Sickness}, {@spell Web}

subclassFeature.name: Land's Aid
entries: As a {@action Magic} action, you can expend a use of your Wild Shape and choose a point within 60 feet of yourself. Vitality-giving flowers and life-draining thorns appear for a moment in a 10-foot-radius {@rule Sphere} centered on that point. Each creature of your choice in the {@rule Sphere} must make a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC, taking {@damage 2d6} Necrotic damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one. One creature of your choice in that area regains 2d6 Hit Points.
The damage and healing increase by 1d6 when you reach Druid levels 10 (3d6) and 14 (4d6).

subclassFeature.name: Natural Recovery
entries: You can cast one of the level 1+ spells that you have prepared from your Circle Spells feature without expending a spell slot, and you must finish a {@rule Long Rest} before you do so again.

In addition, when you finish a {@rule Short Rest}, you can choose expended spell slots to recover. The spell slots can have a combined level that is equal to or less than half your Druid level (round up), and none of them can be level 6+. For example, if you're a level 6 Druid, you can recover up to three levels' worth of spell slots. You can recover a level 3 spell slot, a level 2 and a level 1 spell slot, or three level 1 spell slots. Once you recover spell slots with this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Nature's Ward
entries: You are immune to the {@condition Poisoned} condition, and you have {@rule Resistance} to a damage type associated with your current land choice in the Circle Spells feature, as shown in the {@skill Nature}'s Ward table.

subclassFeature.name: Nature's Sanctuary
entries: As a {@action Magic} action, you can expend a use of your Wild Shape and cause spectral trees and vines to appear in a 15-foot {@rule Cube} on the ground within 120 feet of yourself. They last there for 1 minute or until you have the {@condition Incapacitated} condition or die. You and your allies have {@rule Cover|Half Cover} while in that area, and your allies gain the current {@rule Resistance} of your {@skill Nature}'s Ward while there.
As a {@rule Bonus Action}, you can move the {@rule Cube} up to 60 feet to ground within 120 feet of yourself.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Moon
entries: {@i Adopt Animal Forms to Guard the Wilds}
Druids of the Circle of the Moon draw on lunar magic to transform themselves. Their order gathers under the moon to share news and perform rituals.

Changeable as the moon, a Druid of this circle might prowl as a great cat one night, soar over the treetops as an eagle the next day, and then crash through undergrowth as a bear to drive off a trespassing monster. The wild is in the Druid's blood.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Forms
entries: You can channel lunar magic when you assume a Wild Shape form, granting you the benefits below.

entries.name: Challenge Rating
entries: The maximum {@rule Challenge Rating} for the form equals your Druid level divided by 3 (round down).

entries.name: Armor Class
entries: Until you leave the form, your AC equals 13 plus your Wisdom modifier if that total is higher than the Beast's AC.

entries.name: Temporary Hit Points
entries: You gain a number of {@rule Temporary Hit Points} equal to three times your Druid level.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Moon Spells
entries: When you reach a Druid level specified in the Circle of the Moon Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.
In addition, you can cast the spells from this feature while you're in a Wild Shape form.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Circle Forms
entries: While in a Wild Shape form, you gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Lunar Radiance
entries: Each of your attacks in a Wild Shape form can deal its normal damage type or Radiant damage. You make this choice each time you hit with those attacks.

entries.name: Increased Toughness
entries: You can add your Wisdom modifier to your Constitution saving throws.

subclassFeature.name: Moonlight Step
entries: You magically transport yourself, reappearing amid a burst of moonlight. As a {@rule Bonus Action}, you teleport up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space you can see, and you have {@rule Advantage} on the next attack roll you make before the end of this turn.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}. You can also regain uses by expending a level 2+ spell slot for each use you want to restore (no action required).

subclassFeature.name: Lunar Form
entries: The power of the moon suffuses you, granting you the following benefits.

entries.name: Improved Lunar Radiance
entries: Once per turn, you can deal an extra {@damage 2d10} Radiant damage to a target you hit with a Wild Shape form's attack.

entries.name: Shared Moonlight
entries: Whenever you use Moonlight Step, you can also teleport one willing creature. That creature must be within 10 feet of you, and you teleport it to an unoccupied space you can see within 10 feet of your destination space.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Sea
entries: {@i Become One with Tides and Storms}

Druids of the Circle of the Sea draw on the tempestuous forces of oceans and storms. Some view themselves as embodiments of nature's wrath, seeking vengeance against those who despoil nature. Others seek mystical unity with nature by attuning themselves to the ebb and flow of the tides, following the rush of currents and waves and listening to the inscrutable whispers and roars of the winds.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Sea Spells
entries: When you reach a Druid level specified in the Circle of the Sea Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Circle of the Sea Spells
rows: {@spell Fog Cloud}, {@spell Gust of Wind}, {@spell Ray of Frost}, {@spell Shatter}, {@spell Thunderwave}

subclassFeature.name: Wrath of the Sea
entries: As a {@rule Bonus Action}, you can expend a use of your Wild Shape to manifest a 5-foot {@rule Emanation} that takes the form of ocean spray that surrounds you for 10 minutes. It ends early if you dismiss it (no action required), manifest it again, or have the {@condition Incapacitated} condition.

When you manifest the {@rule Emanation} and as a {@rule Bonus Action} on your subsequent turns, you can choose another creature you can see in the {@rule Emanation}. The target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC or take Cold damage and, if the creature is Large or smaller, be pushed up to 15 feet away from you. To determine this damage, roll a number of d6s equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of one die).

subclassFeature.name: Aquatic Affinity
entries: The size of the {@rule Emanation} created by your Wrath of the Sea increases to 10 feet.
In addition, you gain a {@rule Swim Speed} equal to your {@rule Speed}.

subclassFeature.name: Stormborn
entries: Your Wrath of the Sea confers two more benefits while active, as detailed below.

entries.name: Flight
entries: You gain a {@rule Fly Speed} equal to your {@rule Speed}.

entries.name: Resistance
entries: You have {@rule Resistance} to Cold, Lightning, and Thunder damage.

subclassFeature.name: Oceanic Gift
entries: Instead of manifesting the {@rule Emanation} of Wrath of the Sea around yourself, you can manifest it around one willing creature within 60 feet of yourself. That creature gains all the benefits of the {@rule Emanation} and uses your spell save DC and Wisdom modifier for it.
In addition, you can manifest the {@rule Emanation} around both the other creature and yourself if you expend two uses of your Wild Shape instead of one when manifesting it.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Stars
entries: {@i Harness Secrets Hidden in Constellations}

The Circle of the Stars has tracked heavenly patterns since time immemorial, discovering secrets hidden amid the constellations. By understanding these secrets, the Druids of this circle seek to harness the powers of the cosmos.

subclassFeature.name: Star Map
entries: You've created a star chart as part of your heavenly studies. It is a Tiny object, and you can use it as a {@rule Spellcasting Focus} for your Druid spells. You determine its form by rolling on the Star Map table or by choosing one.

While holding the map, you have the {@spell Guidance} and {@spell Guiding Bolt} spells prepared, and you can cast {@spell Guiding Bolt} without expending a spell slot. You can cast it in that way a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.
If you lose the map, you can perform a 1-hour ceremony to magically create a replacement. This ceremony can be performed during a Short or Long Rest, and it destroys the previous map.

entries.caption: Star Map
rows: A scroll bearing depictions of constellations
A stone tablet with fine holes drilled through it
An owlbear hide tooled with stellar symbols
A collection of maps bound in an ebony cover
A crystal engraved with starry patterns
A glass disk etched with constellations

subclassFeature.name: Starry Form
entries: As a {@rule Bonus Action}, you can expend a use of your Wild Shape feature to take on a starry form rather than shape-shifting.

While in your starry form, you retain your game statistics, but your body becomes luminous, your joints glimmer like stars, and glowing lines connect them as on a star chart. This form sheds {@rule Bright Light} in a 10-foot radius and {@rule Dim Light} for an additional 10 feet. The form lasts for 10 minutes. It ends early if you dismiss it (no action required), have the {@condition Incapacitated} condition, or use this feature again.
Whenever you assume your starry form, choose which of the following constellations glimmers on your body; your choice gives you certain benefits while in the form.

entries.name: Archer
entries: A constellation of an archer appears on you. When you activate this form and as a {@rule Bonus Action} on your subsequent turns while it lasts, you can make a ranged spell attack, hurling a luminous arrow that targets one creature within 60 feet of yourself.
