While entirely in {@rule Darkness}, you have the {@condition Invisible} condition to any creature that relies on {@sense Darkvision} to see you in that {@rule Darkness}. Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

subclassFeature.name: Iron Mind
entries: You have honed your ability to resist mind-altering powers. You gain proficiency in Wisdom saving throws. If you already have this proficiency, you instead gain proficiency in Intelligence or Charisma saving throws (your choice).

subclassFeature.name: Stalker's Flurry
entries: The Psychic damage of your Dreadful Strike becomes 2d8. In addition, when you use the Dreadful Strike effect of your Dread Ambusher feature, you can cause one of the following additional effects.

entries.name: Sudden Strike
entries: You can make another attack with the same weapon against a different creature that is within 5 feet of the original target and that is within the weapon's range.

entries.name: Mass Fear
entries: The target and each creature within 10 feet of it must make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, a creature has the {@condition Frightened} condition until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Shadowy Dodge
entries: When a creature makes an attack roll against you, you can take a {@rule Reaction} to impose {@rule Disadvantage} on that roll. Whether the attack hits or misses, you can then teleport up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space you can see.

subclassFeature.name: Hunter
entries: {@i Protect Nature and People from Destruction}
You stalk prey in the wilds and elsewhere, using your abilities as a Hunter to protect nature and people everywhere from forces that would destroy them.

subclassFeature.name: Hunter's Lore
entries: You can call on the forces of nature to reveal certain strengths and weaknesses of your prey. While a creature is marked by your Hunter's Mark, you know whether that creature has any Immunities, Resistances, or Vulnerabilities, and if the creature has any, you know what they are.

subclassFeature.name: Hunter's Prey
entries: You gain one of the following feature options of your choice. Whenever you finish a Short or Long Rest, you can replace the chosen option with the other one.

entries.name: Colossus Slayer
entries: Your tenacity can wear down even the most resilient foes. When you hit a creature with a weapon, the weapon deals an extra {@damage 1d8} damage to the target if it's missing any of its Hit Points. You can deal this extra damage only once per turn.

entries.name: Horde Breaker
entries: Once on each of your turns when you make an attack with a weapon, you can make another attack with the same weapon against a different creature that is within 5 feet of the original target, that is within the weapon's range, and that you haven't attacked this turn.

subclassFeature.name: Defensive Tactics
entries: You gain one of the following feature options of your choice. Whenever you finish a Short or Long Rest, you can replace the chosen option with the other one.

entries.name: Escape the Horde
entries: {@action Opportunity Attacks} have {@rule Disadvantage} against you.

entries.name: Multiattack Defense
entries: When a creature hits you with an attack roll, that creature has {@rule Disadvantage} on all other attack rolls against you this turn.

subclassFeature.name: Superior Hunter's Prey
entries: Once per turn when you deal damage to a creature marked by your Hunter's Mark, you can also deal that spell's extra damage to a different creature that you can see within 30 feet of the first creature.

subclassFeature.name: Superior Hunter's Defense
entries: When you take damage, you can take a {@rule Reaction} to give yourself {@rule Resistance} to that damage and any other damage of the same type until the end of the current turn.

fluff.name: Rogue
entries: Stealthy killers who are defined by their ability to hit enemies where it will cause the most damage. Rogues used honed skill and quick hands to approach, kill, and retreat before the target can respond.

weapons: Martial weapons that have the Finesse or Light property

entries: {@i Choose A or B:} (A) {@item Leather Armor}, 2 {@item Dagger|Daggers}, {@item Shortsword}, {@item Shortbow}, {@item Arrows (20)|20 Arrows}, {@item Quiver}, {@item Thieves' Tools}, {@item Burglar's Pack}, and 8 GP; or (B) 100 GP

classFeature.name: Sneak Attack
entries: You know how to strike subtly and exploit a foe's distraction. Once per turn, you can deal an extra {@damage 1d6} damage to one creature you hit with an attack roll if you have {@rule Advantage} on the roll and the attack uses a Finesse or a Ranged weapon. The extra damage's type is the same as the weapon's type.

You don't need {@rule Advantage} on the attack roll if at least one of your allies is within 5 feet of the target, the ally doesn't have the {@condition Incapacitated} condition, and you don't have {@rule Disadvantage} on the attack roll.
The extra damage increases as you gain Rogue levels, as shown in the Sneak Attack column of the Rogue Features table.

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: You gain {@rule Expertise} in two of your skill proficiencies of your choice. {@skill Sleight of Hand} and {@skill Stealth} are recommended if you have proficiency in them.
At Rogue level 6, you gain {@rule Expertise} in two more of your skill proficiencies of your choice.

classFeature.name: Thieves' Cant
entries: You picked up various languages in the communities where you plied your roguish talents. You know Thieves' Cant and one other language of your choice.

classFeature.name: Weapon Mastery
entries: Your training with weapons allows you to use the mastery properties of two kinds of weapons of your choice with which you have proficiency, such as {@item Dagger|Daggers} and {@item Shortbow|Shortbows}.

Whenever you finish a {@rule Long Rest}, you can change the kinds of weapons you chose. For example, you could switch to using the mastery properties of {@item Scimitar|Scimitars} and {@item Shortsword|Shortswords}.

classFeature.name: Cunning Action
entries: Your quick thinking and agility allow you to move and act quickly. On your turn, you can take one of the following actions as a {@rule Bonus Action}: {@action Dash}, {@action Disengage}, or {@action Hide}.

classFeature.name: Rogue Subclass
entries: You gain a Rogue subclass of your choice. A subclass is a specialization that grants you features at certain Rogue levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your subclass's features that are of your Rogue level or lower.

classFeature.name: Steady Aim
entries: As a {@rule Bonus Action}, you give yourself {@rule Advantage} on your next attack roll on the current turn. You can use this feature only if you haven't moved during this turn, and after you use it, your {@rule Speed} is 0 until the end of the current turn.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Rogue levels 8, 10, 12, and 16.

classFeature.name: Cunning Strike
entries: You've developed cunning ways to use your Sneak Attack. When you deal Sneak Attack damage, you can add one of the following Cunning Strike effects. Each effect has a die cost, which is the number of Sneak Attack damage dice you must forgo to add the effect. You remove the die before rolling, and the effect occurs immediately after the attack's damage is dealt. For example, if you add the Poison effect, remove 1d6 from the Sneak Attack's damage before rolling.
If a Cunning Strike effect requires a saving throw, the DC equals 8 plus your Dexterity modifier and {@rule Proficiency} Bonus.

classFeature.name: Poison
entries: You add a toxin to your strike, forcing the target to make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the target has the {@condition Poisoned} condition for 1 minute. At the end of each of its turns, the {@condition Poisoned} target repeats the save, ending the effect on itself on a success.
To use this effect, you must have a {@item Poisoner's Kit} on your person.

classFeature.name: Trip
entries: If the target is Large or smaller, it must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or have the {@condition Prone} condition.

classFeature.name: Withdraw
entries: Immediately after the attack, you move up to half your {@rule Speed} without provoking {@action Opportunity Attack|Opportunity Attacks}.

classFeature.name: Uncanny Dodge
entries: When an attacker that you can see hits you with an attack roll, you can take a {@rule Reaction} to halve the attack's damage against you (round down).

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: You gain {@rule Expertise} in two of your Skill Proficiencies of your choice.

classFeature.name: Evasion
entries: You can nimbly dodge out of the way of certain dangers. When you're subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw and only half damage if you fail. You can't use this feature if you have the {@condition Incapacitated} condition.

classFeature.name: Reliable Talent
entries: Whenever you make an ability check that uses one of your skill or tool proficiencies, you can treat a d20 roll of 9 or lower as a 10.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Rogue Subclass.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Improved Cunning Strike
entries: You can use up to two Cunning Strike effects when you deal Sneak Attack damage, paying the die cost for each effect.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Rogue Subclass.

classFeature.name: Devious Strikes
entries: You've practiced new ways to use your Sneak Attack deviously. The following effects are now among your Cunning Strike options.

classFeature.name: Daze
entries: The target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw, or on its next turn, it can do only one of the following: move or take an action or a {@rule Bonus Action}.

classFeature.name: Knock Out
entries: The target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw, or it has the {@condition Unconscious} condition for 1 minute or until it takes any damage. The {@condition Unconscious} target repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

classFeature.name: Obscure
entries: The target must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw, or it has the {@condition Blinded} condition until the end of its next turn.

classFeature.name: Slippery Mind
entries: Your cunning mind is exceptionally difficult to control. You gain proficiency in Wisdom and Charisma saving throws.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Rogue Subclass.

classFeature.name: Elusive
entries: You're so evasive that attackers rarely gain the upper hand against you. No attack roll can have {@rule Advantage} against you unless you have the {@condition Incapacitated} condition.

classFeature.name: Epic Boon
entries: You gain an {@epic-boon Epic Boon} or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify. {@epic-boon Boon of the Night Spirit} is recommended.

classFeature.name: Stroke of Luck
entries: You have a marvelous knack for succeeding when you need to. If you fail a {@rule D20 Test}, you can turn the roll into a 20.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a Short or Long Rest.

subclassFeature.name: Assassin
entries: {@i Practice the Grim Art of Death}

An Assassin's training focuses on using stealth, poison, and disguise to eliminate foes with deadly efficiency. While some Rogues who follow this path are hired killers, spies, or bounty hunters, the capabilities of this subclass are equally useful for adventurers facing a variety of monstrous enemies.

subclassFeature.name: Assassin's Tools
entries: You gain a {@item Disguise Kit} and a {@item Poisoner's Kit}, and you have proficiency with them.

subclassFeature.name: Assassinate
entries: You're adept at ambushing a target, granting you the following benefits.

entries.name: Initiative
entries: You have {@rule Advantage} on {@rule Initiative} rolls.

entries.name: Deadly
entries: You use d8s when rolling damage for your Sneak Attack, instead of d6s.

entries.name: Surprising Strikes
entries: During the first round of each combat, you have {@rule Advantage} on attack rolls against any creature that hasn't taken a turn. If your Sneak Attack hits any target during that round, the target takes extra damage of the weapon's type equal to your Rogue level.

subclassFeature.name: Infiltration Expertise
entries: You are expert at the following techniques that aid your infiltrations.

entries.name: Masterful Mimicry
entries: You can unerringly mimic another person's speech, handwriting, or both if you have spent at least 1 hour studying them.

entries.name: Roving Aim
entries: Your {@rule Speed} isn't reduced to 0 by using Steady Aim.

subclassFeature.name: Envenom Weapons
entries: When you use the Poison option of your Cunning Strike, the target also takes {@damage 2d6} Poison damage whenever it fails the saving throw. This damage ignores {@rule Resistance} to Poison damage.

subclassFeature.name: Death Strike
entries: When you hit with your Sneak Attack on the first round of a combat, the target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw (DC 8 plus your Dexterity modifier and {@rule Proficiency} Bonus), or the attack's damage is doubled against the target.

subclassFeature.name: Soulknife
entries: {@i Strike Foes with Psionic Blades}

A Soulknife strikes with the mind, cutting through barriers both physical and psychic. These Rogues discover psionic power within themselves and channel it to do their roguish work. As a Soulknife, your psionic abilities might have haunted you since childhood, revealing their full potential only as you experienced the stress of adventure. Or you might have sought out an order of psychic adepts and spent years learning how to manifest your power.

subclassFeature.name: Psionic Power
entries: You harbor a wellspring of psionic energy within yourself. It is represented by your Psionic Energy Dice, which fuel certain powers you have from this subclass. The Soulknife Energy Dice table shows the number of these dice you have when you reach certain Rogue levels, and the table shows the die size.

Any features in this subclass that use a Psionic Energy Die use only the dice from this subclass. Some of your powers expend a Psionic Energy Die, as specified in a power's description, and you can't use a power if it requires you to use a die when your Psionic Energy Dice are all expended.
You regain one of your expended Psionic Energy Dice when you finish a {@rule Short Rest}, and you regain all of them when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

entries.name: Psi-Bolstered Knack
entries: If you fail an ability check using a skill or tool with which you have proficiency, you can roll one Psionic Energy Die and add the number rolled to the check, potentially turning failure into success. The die is expended only if the roll then succeeds.

entries.name: Psychic Whispers
entries: You can establish telepathic communication between yourself and others. As a {@action Magic} action, choose one or more creatures you can see, up to a number of creatures equal to your {@rule Proficiency} Bonus, and then roll one Psionic Energy Die. For a number of hours equal to the number rolled, the chosen creatures can speak telepathically with you, and you can speak telepathically with them. To send or receive a message (no action required), you and the other creature must be within 1 mile of each other. A creature can end the telepathic connection at any time (no action required).
The first time you use this power after each {@rule Long Rest}, you don't expend the Psionic Energy Die. All other times you use the power, you expend the die.

subclassFeature.name: Psychic Blades
entries: You can manifest shimmering blades of psychic energy. Whenever you take the {@action Attack} action or make an {@action Opportunity Attack}, you can manifest a {@item Psychic Blade} in your free hand and make the attack with that blade. The magic blade has the following traits:
The blade vanishes immediately after it hits or misses its target, and it leaves no mark if it deals damage.

After you attack with the blade on your turn, you can make a melee or ranged attack with a second psychic blade as a {@rule Bonus Action} on the same turn if your other hand is free to create it. The damage die of this bonus attack is 1d4 instead of 1d6.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Blades
entries: You can now use the following powers with your Psychic Blades.

entries.name: Homing Strikes
entries: If you make an attack roll with your {@item Psychic Blade} and miss the target, you can roll one Psionic Energy Die and add the number rolled to the attack roll. If this causes the attack to hit, the die is expended.

entries.name: Psychic Teleportation
entries: As a {@rule Bonus Action}, you manifest a {@item Psychic Blade}, expend one Psionic Energy Die and roll it, and throw the blade at an unoccupied space you can see up to a number of feet away equal to 10 times the number rolled. You then teleport to that space, and the blade vanishes.

subclassFeature.name: Psychic Veil
entries: You can weave a veil of psychic static to mask yourself. As a {@action Magic} action, you gain the {@condition Invisible} condition for 1 hour or until you dismiss this effect (no action required). This invisibility ends early immediately after you deal damage to a creature or you force a creature to make a saving throw.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest} unless you expend a Psionic Energy Die (no action required) to restore your use of it.

subclassFeature.name: Rend Mind
entries: You can sweep your Psychic Blades through a creature's mind. When you use your Psychic Blades to deal Sneak Attack damage to a creature, you can force that target to make a Wisdom saving throw (DC 8 plus your Dexterity modifier and {@rule Proficiency} Bonus). If the save fails, the target has the {@condition Stunned} condition for 1 minute. The {@condition Stunned} target repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest} unless you expend three Psionic Energy Dice (no action required) to restore your use of it.

subclassFeature.name: Thief
entries: {@i Hunt for Treasure as a Classic Adventurer}

A mix of burglar, treasure hunter, and explorer, you are the epitome of an adventurer. In addition to improving your agility and stealth, you gain abilities useful for delving into ruins and getting maximum benefit from the magic items you find there.

subclassFeature.name: Fast Hands
entries: As a {@rule Bonus Action}, you can do one of the following.

entries.name: Sleight of Hand
entries: Make a Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) check to pick a lock or disarm a trap with {@item Thieves' Tools} or to pick a pocket.

entries.name: Use an Object
entries: Take the {@action Utilize} action, or take the {@action Magic} action to use a magic item that requires that action.

subclassFeature.name: Second-Story Work
entries: You've trained to get into especially hard-to-reach places, granting you these benefits.

entries.name: Climber
entries: You gain a {@rule Climb Speed} equal to your {@rule Speed}.

entries.name: Jumper
entries: You can determine your jump distance using your Dexterity rather than your Strength.

subclassFeature.name: Supreme Sneak
entries: You gain the following Cunning Strike option.

entries.name: Stealth Attack (Cost: 1d6)
entries: If you have the {@action Hide} action's {@condition Invisible} condition, this attack doesn't end that condition on you if you end the turn behind {@rule Cover|Three-Quarters Cover} or {@rule Cover|Total Cover}.

subclassFeature.name: Use Magic Device
entries: You've learned how to maximize use of magic items, granting you the following benefits.

entries.name: Attunement
entries: You can attune to up to four magic items at once.

entries.name: Charges
entries: Whenever you use a magic item property that expends charges, roll 1d6. On a roll of 6, you use the property without expending the charges.

entries.name: Scrolls
entries: You can use any {@item Spell Scroll}, using Intelligence as your spellcasting ability for the spell. If the spell is a cantrip or a level 1 spell, you can cast it reliably. If the scroll contains a higher-level spell, you must first succeed on an Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check (DC 10 plus the spell's level). On a successful check, you cast the spell from the scroll. On a failed check, the scroll disintegrates.

subclassFeature.name: Thief's Reflexes
entries: You are adept at laying ambushes and quickly escaping danger. You can take two turns during the first round of any combat. You take your first turn at your normal {@rule Initiative} and your second turn at your {@rule Initiative} minus 10.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Trickster
entries: {@i Enhance Stealth with Arcane Spells}

Some Rogues enhance their fine-honed skills of stealth and agility with spells, learning magical tricks to aid them in their trade. Some Arcane Tricksters use their talents as pickpockets and burglars, while others are pranksters.

subclassFeature.name: Mage Hand Legerdemain
entries: When you cast {@spell Mage Hand}, you can cast it as a {@rule Bonus Action}, and you can make the spectral hand {@condition Invisible}. You can control the hand as a {@rule Bonus Action}, and through it, you can make Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) checks.

subclassFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: You have learned to cast spells. The information below details how you use those rules as an Arcane Trickster.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You know three cantrips: {@spell Mage Hand} and two other cantrips of your choice from the {@spells ?spell-class-filter=wizard|Wizard spell list}. {@spell Mind Sliver} and {@spell Minor Illusion} are recommended.
Whenever you gain a Rogue level, you can replace one of your cantrips, except {@spell Mage Hand}, with another Wizard cantrip of your choice.
When you reach Rogue level 10, you learn another Wizard cantrip of your choice.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Arcane Trickster Spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your level 1+ spells. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

entries.name: Prepared Spells of 1st+ Level
entries: You prepare the list of level 1+ spells that are available for you to cast with this feature. To start, choose three level 1 Wizard spells. {@spell Find Familiar}, {@spell Disguise Self}, and {@spell Fog Cloud} are recommended.

The number of spells on your list increases as you gain Rogue levels, as shown in the Spells column of the Arcane Trickster Spellcasting table. Whenever that number increases, choose additional Wizard spells until the number of spells on your list matches the number in the Arcane Trickster Spellcasting table. The chosen spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For example, if you're a level 7 Rogue, your list of prepared spells can include five Wizard spells of level 1 or 2 in any combination.

entries.name: Changing Your Prepared Spells
entries: Whenever you gain a Rogue level, you can replace one spell on your list with another Wizard spell for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your Wizard spells.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use an {@item Arcane Focus} as a {@rule Spellcasting Focus} for your Wizard spells.

subclassFeature.name: Magical Ambush
entries: If you have the {@condition Invisible} condition when you cast a spell on a creature, it has {@rule Disadvantage} on any saving throw it makes against the spell on the same turn.

subclassFeature.name: Versatile Trickster
entries: You gain the ability to distract targets with your {@spell Mage Hand}. When you use the Trip option of your Cunning Strike on a creature, you can also use that option on another creature within 5 feet of the spectral hand.

subclassFeature.name: Spell Thief
entries: You gain the ability to magically steal the knowledge of how to cast a spell from another spellcaster.

Immediately after a creature casts a spell that targets you or includes you in its area of effect, you can take a {@rule Reaction} to force the creature to make an Intelligence saving throw. The DC equals your spell save DC. On a failed save, you negate the spell's effect against you, and you steal the knowledge of the spell if it is at least level 1 and of a level you can cast (it doesn't need to be a Wizard spell). For the next 8 hours, you have the spell prepared. The creature can't cast it until the 8 hours have passed.
Once you steal a spell with this feature, you can't use this feature again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

fluff.name: Sorcerer
entries: Arcane casters defined by their ability to alter the effects of spells they cast. Sorcerers use their own inborn talents and power to become an unending battery of magical effects.
{@i Choose A or B:} (A) {@item Spear}, 2 {@item Dagger|Daggers}, {@item Arcane Focus} ({@item crystal}), {@item Dungeoneer's Pack}, and 28 GP; or (B) 50 GP

classFeature.name: Innate Sorcery
entries: An event in your past left an indelible mark on you, infusing you with simmering magic. As a {@rule Bonus Action}, you can unleash that magic for 1 minute, during which you gain the following benefits:

items: The spell save DC of your Sorcerer spells increases by 1.
You have {@rule Advantage} on the attack rolls of Sorcerer spells you cast.

entries: You can use this feature twice, and you regain all expended uses of it when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: Drawing from your innate magic, you can cast spells. The information below details how you use those rules with Sorcerer spells, which appear in the {@spells ?spell-class-filter=sorcerer|Sorcerer spell list}.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You know four Sorcerer cantrips of your choice. {@spell Elementalism}, {@spell Light}, {@spell Message}, and {@spell Sorcerous Burst} are recommended. Whenever you gain a Sorcerer level, you can replace one of your cantrips from this feature with another Sorcerer cantrip of your choice.
When you reach Sorcerer levels 4 and 10, you learn another Sorcerer cantrip of your choice, as shown in the Cantrips column of the Sorcerer Features table.

entries.name: Spell Points
entries: Your unique way of accessing the Weave means you use spell points to cast your spells instead of slots like all other magic users. To cast a spell with spell points, you expend a number of points equal to the level of the spell you're casting. You can't reduce your spell points total to less than 0, and you regain all spent spell points when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

Spells of 6th level and higher are particularly taxing to cast. You can use spell points to cast one spell of each level 6th or higher then you can't cast another spell of the same level until you finish a long rest.

The number of spell points you have to spend is based on your level as a spellcaster, per the Sorcerer table. Your level also determines the maximum-level spell you can cast. Even if you have enough points to cast a spell above that level, you can't do so.

entries.name: Prepared Spells of Level 1+
entries: You prepare the list of level 1+ spells that are available for you to cast with this feature. To start, choose two level 1 Sorcerer spells. {@spell Chromatic Orb} and {@spell Shield} are recommended.

The number of spells on your list increases as you gain Sorcerer levels, as shown in the Spells column of the Sorcerer Features table. Whenever that number increases, choose additional Sorcerer spells until the number of spells on your list matches the number in the Sorcerer Features table. The chosen spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For example, if you're a level 3 Sorcerer, your list of prepared spells can include six Sorcerer spells of level 1 or 2 in any combination.

If another Sorcerer feature gives you spells that you always have prepared, those spells don't count against the number of spells you can prepare with this feature, but those spells otherwise count as Sorcerer spells for you.

entries.name: Changing Your Prepared Spells
entries: Whenever you gain a Sorcerer level, you can replace one spell on your list with another Sorcerer spell for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your Sorcerer spells.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use an {@item Arcane Focus} as a {@rule Spellcasting Focus} for your Sorcerer spells.

classFeature.name: Font of Magic
entries: You can tap into the wellspring of magic within yourself. This wellspring is represented by Sorcery Points, which allow you to create a variety of magical effects.

You have 2 Sorcery Points, and you gain more as you reach higher levels, as shown in the Sorcery Points column of the Sorcerer Features table. You can't have more Sorcery Points than the number shown in the table for your level. You regain all expended Sorcery Points when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.
You can use your Sorcery Points to fuel the options below, along with other features, such as Metamagic, that use those points.

entries.name: Converting Spell Slots to Sorcery Points
entries: As a bonus action on your turn, you can expend any number of sorcery points to create that many spell points. Alternately, you can expend any number of spell points to create that many sorcery points. Any extra spell points vanish at the end of a long rest. You still can't have more sorcery points than shown in the Sorcerer table.

classFeature.name: Metamagic
entries: Because your magic flows from within, you can alter your spells to suit your needs; you gain two Metamagic options of your choice from Metamagic Options. You use the chosen options to temporarily modify spells you cast. To use an option, you must spend the number of Sorcery Points that it costs.
You can use only one Metamagic option on a spell when you cast it unless otherwise noted in one of those options.
Whenever you gain a Sorcerer level, you can replace one of your Metamagic options with one you don't know. You gain two more options at Sorcerer level 10 and two more at Sorcerer level 17.

classFeature.name: Sorcerer Subclass
entries: You gain a Sorcerer subclass of your choice. A subclass is a specialization that grants you features at certain Sorcerer levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your subclass's features that are of your Sorcerer level or lower.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Sorcerer levels 8, 12, and 16.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Restoration
entries: When you finish a {@rule Short Rest}, you can regain expended Sorcery Points, but no more than a number equal to half your Sorcerer level (round down). Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Sorcerer subclass.

classFeature.name: Sorcery Incarnate
entries: If you have no uses of Innate Sorcery left, you can use it if you spend 2 Sorcery Points when you take the {@rule Bonus Action} to activate it.
In addition, while your Innate Sorcery feature is active, you can use up to two of your Metamagic Options on each spell you cast.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Metamagic
entries: Because your magic flows from within you, you can alter your spells to suit your needs; you gain two Metamagic options of your choice from the Metamagic Options.
You can use only one Metamagic option on a spell when you cast it, unless otherwise noted in one of those options.
Whenever you gain a Sorcerer level, you can replace one of your Metamagic options with one you don't know.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Sorcerer subclass.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Metamagic
entries: Because your magic flows from within you, you can alter your spells to suit your needs; you gain two Metamagic options of your choice from the Metamagic Options.
You can use only one Metamagic option on a spell when you cast it, unless otherwise noted in one of those options.
Whenever you gain a Sorcerer level, you can replace one of your Metamagic options with one you don't know.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Sorcerer subclass.

classFeature.name: Epic Boon
entries: You gain an {@epic-boon Epic Boon} or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify. {@epic-boon Boon of Dimensional Travel} is recommended.

classFeature.name: Arcane Apotheosis
entries: While your Innate Sorcery feature is active, you can use one Metamagic option on each of your turns without spending Sorcery Points on it.

subclassFeature.name: Aberrant Sorcery
entries: {@i Wield Unnatural Psionic Power}

An alien influence has wrapped its tendrils around your mind, giving you psionic power. You can now touch other minds with that power and alter the world around you. Will this power shine from you as a hopeful beacon to others? Or will you be a terror to those who feel the stab of your mind?

Perhaps a psychic wind from the Astral Plane carried psionic energy to you, or you were exposed to the Far Realm's warping influence. Alternatively, you were implanted with a mind flayer tadpole, but your transformation into a mind flayer never occurred; now the tadpole's psionic power is yours. However you acquired this power, your mind is aflame with it.

subclassFeature.name: Psionic Spells
entries: When you reach a Sorcerer level specified in the Psionic Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Psionic Spells
rows: {@spell Arms of Hadar}, {@spell Calm Emotions}, {@spell Detect Thoughts}, {@spell Dissonant Whispers}, {@spell Mind Sliver}

subclassFeature.name: Telepathic Speech
entries: You can form a telepathic connection between your mind and the mind of another. As a {@rule Bonus Action}, choose one creature you can see within 30 feet of yourself. You and the chosen creature can communicate telepathically with each other while the two of you are within a number of miles of each other equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1 mile). To understand each other, you each must mentally use a language the other knows.
The telepathic connection lasts for a number of minutes equal to your Sorcerer level. It ends early if you use this ability to form a connection with a different creature.

subclassFeature.name: Psionic Sorcery
entries: When you cast any level 1+ spell from your Psionic Spells feature, you can cast it by expending a spell slot as normal or by spending a number of Sorcery Points equal to the spell's level. If you cast the spell using Sorcery Points, it requires no Verbal or Somatic components, and it requires no Material components unless they are consumed by the spell or have a cost specified in it.

subclassFeature.name: Psychic Defenses
entries: You have {@rule Resistance} to Psychic damage, and you have {@rule Advantage} on saving throws to avoid or end the {@condition Charmed} or {@condition Frightened} condition.

subclassFeature.name: Revelation in Flesh
entries: You can unleash the aberrant truth hidden within yourself. As a {@rule Bonus Action}, you can spend 1 Sorcery Point or more to magically alter your body for 10 minutes. For each Sorcery Point you spend, you gain one of the following benefits of your choice, the effects of which last until the alteration ends.

entries.name: Aquatic Adaptation
entries: You gain a {@rule Swim Speed} equal to twice your {@rule Speed}, and you can breathe underwater. Gills grow from your neck or flare behind your ears, and your fingers become webbed or you grow wriggling cilia.

entries.name: Glistening Flight
entries: You gain a {@rule Fly Speed} equal to your {@rule Speed}, and you can hover. As you fly, your skin glistens with mucus or otherworldly light.

entries.name: See the Invisible
entries: You can see any {@condition Invisible} creature within 60 feet of yourself that isn't behind {@rule Cover|Total Cover}. Your eyes also turn black or become writhing sensory tendrils.

entries.name: Wormlike Movement
entries: Your body, along with any equipment you are wearing or carrying, becomes slimy and pliable. You can move through any space as narrow as 1 inch, and you can spend 5 feet of movement to escape from nonmagical restraints or the {@condition Grappled} condition.

subclassFeature.name: Warping Implosion
entries: You can unleash a space-warping anomaly. As a {@action Magic} action, you teleport to an unoccupied space you can see within 120 feet of yourself. Immediately after you disappear, each creature within 30 feet of the space you left must make a Strength saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, a creature takes {@damage 3d10} Force damage and is pulled straight toward the space you left, ending in an unoccupied space as close to your former space as possible. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage only.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest} unless you spend 5 Sorcery Points (no action required) to restore your use of it.

subclassFeature.name: Clockwork Sorcery
entries: {@i Channel Cosmic Forces of Order}

The cosmic force of order has suffused you with magic. That power arises from Mechanus or a realm like it—a plane of existence shaped entirely by clockwork efficiency. You or someone from your lineage might have become entangled in the machinations of modrons, the orderly beings who inhabit Mechanus. Perhaps your ancestor even took part in the Great Modron March. Whatever its origin within you, the power of order can seem strange to others, but for you, it's part of a vast and glorious system.

subclassFeature.name: Clockwork Spells
entries: When you reach a Sorcerer level specified in the Clockwork Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Clockwork Spells
rows: {@spell Aid}, {@spell Alarm}, {@spell Lesser Restoration}, {@spell Protection from Evil and Good}

entries: In addition, consult the Manifestations of Order table and choose or randomly determine a way your connection to order manifests while you are casting any of your Sorcerer spells.

entries.caption: Manifestations of Order
rows: The hands of a clock spin in your eyes.
Your skin glows with a brassy sheen.
Floating equations and geometric objects overlay your body.
Your {@rule Spellcasting Focus} temporarily takes the form of a Tiny clockwork mechanism.
The ticking of gears or ringing of a clock can be heard by you and those affected by your magic.

subclassFeature.name: Restore Balance
entries: Your connection to the plane of absolute order allows you to equalize chaotic moments. When a creature you can see within 60 feet of yourself is about to roll a d20 with {@rule Advantage} or {@rule Disadvantage}, you can take a {@rule Reaction} to prevent the roll from being affected by {@rule Advantage} and {@rule Disadvantage}.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Bastion of Law
entries: You can tap into the grand equation of existence to imbue a creature with a shimmering shield of order. As a {@action Magic} action, you can expend 1 to 5 Sorcery Points to create a magical ward around yourself or another creature you can see within 30 feet of yourself. The ward is represented by a number of d8s equal to the number of Sorcery Points spent to create it. When the warded creature takes damage, it can expend a number of those dice, roll them, and reduce the damage taken by the total rolled on those dice.
The ward lasts until you finish a {@rule Long Rest} or until you use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Trance of Order
entries: You gain the ability to align your consciousness with the endless calculations of Mechanus. As a {@rule Bonus Action}, you can enter this state for 1 minute. For the duration, attack rolls against you can't benefit from {@rule Advantage}, and whenever you make a {@rule D20 Test}, you can treat a roll of 9 or lower on the d20 as a 10.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest} unless you spend 5 Sorcery Points (no action required) to restore your use of it.

subclassFeature.name: Clockwork Cavalcade
entries: You momentarily summon spirits of order to expunge disorder around you. As a {@action Magic} action, you summon the spirits in a 30-foot {@rule Cube} originating from you. The spirits look like modrons or other Constructs of your choice. The spirits are intangible and invulnerable, and they create the effects below within the {@rule Cube} before vanishing. Once you use this action, you can't use it again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest} unless you spend 7 Sorcery Points (no action required) to restore your use of it.

entries.name: Heal
entries: The spirits restore up to 100 Hit Points, divided as you choose among any number of creatures of your choice in the {@rule Cube}.

entries.name: Repair
entries: Any damaged objects entirely in the {@rule Cube} are repaired instantly.

entries.name: Dispel
entries: Every spell of level 6 and lower ends on creatures and objects of your choice in the {@rule Cube}.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Sorcery
entries: {@i Breathe the Magic of Dragons}

Your innate magic comes from the gift of a dragon. Perhaps an ancient dragon facing death bequeathed some of its magical power to you or your ancestor. You might have absorbed magic from a site infused with dragons' power. Or perhaps you handled a treasure taken from a dragon's hoard that was steeped in draconic power. Or you might have a dragon for an ancestor.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Spells
entries: When you reach a Sorcerer level specified in the Draconic Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Psionic Spells
rows: {@spell Alter Self}, {@spell Chromatic Orb}, {@spell Command}, {@spell Dragon's Breath}

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Resilience
entries: The magic in your body manifests physical traits of your draconic gift. Your {@rule Hit Points|Hit Point} maximum increases by 3, and it increases by 1 whenever you gain another Sorcerer level.
Parts of you are also covered by dragon-like scales. While you aren't wearing armor, your base {@rule Armor Class} equals 10 plus your Dexterity and Charisma modifiers.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Affinity
entries: Your draconic magic has an affinity with a damage type associated with dragons. Choose one of those types: Acid, Cold, Fire, Lightning, or Poison.
You have {@rule Resistance} to that damage type, and when you cast a spell that deals damage of that type, you can add your Charisma modifier to one damage roll of that spell.

subclassFeature.name: Dragon Wings
entries: As a {@rule Bonus Action}, you can cause draconic wings to appear on your back. The wings last for 1 hour or until you dismiss them (no action required). For the duration, you have a {@rule Fly Speed} of 60 feet.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest} unless you spend 3 Sorcery Points (no action required) to restore your use of it.

subclassFeature.name: Dragon Companion
entries: You can cast {@spell Summon Dragon} without a Material component. You can also cast it once without a spell slot, and you regain the ability to cast it in this way when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.
Whenever you start casting the spell, you can modify it so that it doesn't require {@status Concentration}. If you do so, the spell's duration becomes 1 minute for that casting.

subclassFeature.name: Wild Magic Sorcery
entries: {@i Unleash Chaotic Magic}

Your innate magic stems from the forces of chaos that underlie the order of creation. You or an ancestor might have endured exposure to raw magic, perhaps through a planar portal leading to Limbo or the Elemental Planes. Perhaps you were blessed by a fey being or marked by a demon. Or your magic could be a fluke with no apparent cause. Whatever its source, this magic churns within you, waiting for any outlet.

subclassFeature.name: Tides of Chaos
entries: You can manipulate chaos itself to give yourself {@rule Advantage} on one {@rule D20 Test} before you roll the d20. Once you do so, you must cast a Sorcerer spell with a spell slot or finish a {@rule Long Rest} before you can use this feature again.
If you do cast a Sorcerer spell with a spell slot before you finish a {@rule Long Rest}, you automatically roll on the {@table Wild Magic Surge} table.

subclassFeature.name: Wild Magic Surge
entries: Your spellcasting can unleash surges of untamed magic. Once per turn, you can roll 1d20 immediately after you cast a Sorcerer spell with a spell slot. If you roll a 20, roll on the Wild Magic Surge table to create a magical effect.
If the magical effect is a spell, it is too wild to be affected by your Metamagic.

entries.caption: Wild Magic Surge
rows: Roll on this table at the start of each of your turns for the next minute, ignoring this result on subsequent rolls.

A creature that is Friendly toward you appears in a random unoccupied space within 60 feet of you. The creature is under the DM's control and disappears 1 minute later. Roll 1d4 to determine the creature: on a 1, a Modron Duodrone appears; on a 2, a Flumph appears; on a 3, a Modron Monodrone appears; on a 4, a Unicorn appears. See the Monster Manual for the creature's stat block.
For the next minute, you regain 5 Hit Points at the start of each of your turns.
Creatures have {@rule Disadvantage} on saving throws against the next spell you cast in the next minute that involves a saving throw.

You are subjected to an effect that lasts for 1 minute unless its description says otherwise. Roll 1d8 to determine the effect: on a 1, you're surrounded by faint, ethereal music only you and creatures within 5 feet of you can hear; on a 2, your size increases by one size category; on a 3, you grow a long beard made of feathers that remains until you sneeze, at which point the feathers explode from your face and vanish; on a 4, you must shout when you speak; on a 5, illusory butterflies flutter in the air within 10 feet of you; on a 6, an eye appears on your forehead, granting you {@rule Advantage} on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks; on an 7, pink bubbles float out of your mouth whenever you speak; on an 8, your skin turns a vibrant shade of blue for 24 hours or until the effect is ended by a {@spell Remove Curse} spell.
For the next minute, all your spells with a casting time of an action have a casting time of a {@rule Bonus Action}.
You are transported to the Astral Plane until the end of your next turn. You then return to the space you previously occupied or the nearest unoccupied space if that space is occupied.
The next time you cast a spell that deals damage within the next minute, don't roll the spell's damage dice for the damage. Instead use the highest number possible for each damage die.
You have {@rule Resistance} to all damage for the next minute.

You turn into a potted plant until the start of your next turn. While you're a plant, you have the {@condition Incapacitated} condition and have {@rule Vulnerability} to all damage. If you drop to 0 Hit Points, your pot breaks, and your form reverts.
For the next minute, you can teleport up to 20 feet as a {@rule Bonus Action} on each of your turns.

You and up to three creatures you choose within 30 feet of you have the {@condition Invisible} condition for 1 minute. This invisibility ends on a creature immediately after it makes an attack roll, deals damage, or casts a spell.
A spectral shield hovers near you for the next minute, granting you a +2 bonus to AC and immunity to {@spell Magic Missile}.
You can take one extra action on this turn.

You cast a random spell. If the spell normally requires {@status Concentration}, it doesn't require {@status Concentration} in this case; the spell lasts for its full duration. Roll 1d10 to determine the spell: on a 1, {@spell Confusion}; on a 2, {@spell Fireball}; on a 3, {@spell Fog Cloud}; on a 4, {@spell Fly} (cast on a random creature within 60 feet of you), on a 5, {@spell Grease}; on a 6, {@spell Levitate} (cast on yourself); on a 7, {@spell Magic Missile} (cast as a level 5 spell); on an 8, {@spell Mirror Image}; on a 9, {@spell Polymorph} (cast on yourself), and if you fail the saving throw, you turn into a Goat (see appendix B); on a 10, See {@spell Invisibility}.
For the next minute, any flammable, nonmagical object you touch that isn't being worn or carried by another creature bursts into flame, takes {@damage 1d4} Fire damage, and is burning.
If you die within the next hour, you immediately revive as if by the {@spell Reincarnate} spell.
You have the {@condition Frightened} condition until the end of your next turn. The DM determines the source of your fear.
You teleport up to 60 feet to an unoccupied space you can see.
A random creature within 60 feet of you has the {@condition Poisoned} condition for 1d4 hours.
You radiate {@rule Bright Light} in a 30-foot radius for the next minute. Any creature that ends its turn within 5 feet of you has the {@condition Blinded} condition until the end of its next turn.
Up to three creatures of your choice that you can see within 30 feet of you take {@damage 1d10} Necrotic damage. You regain Hit Points equal to the sum of the Necrotic damage dealt.
Up to three creatures of your choice that you can see within 30 feet of you take {@damage 4d10} Lightning damage.
You and all creatures within 30 feet of you have {@rule Vulnerability} to Piercing damage for the next minute.

Roll 1d6 On a 1, you regain 2d10 Hit Points; on a 2, one ally of your choice within 300 feet of you regains 2d10 Hit Points; on a 3, you regain your lowest-level expended spell slot; on a 4, one ally of your choice within 300 feet of you regains their lowest-level expended spell slot; on a 5, you regain all your expended Sorcery Points; on a 6, all the effects of row 17–20 affect you simultaneously.

subclassFeature.name: Bend Luck
entries: You have the ability to twist fate using your wild magic. Immediately after another creature you can see rolls the d20 for a {@rule D20 Test}, you can take a {@rule Reaction} and spend 1 Sorcery Point to roll 1d4 and apply the number rolled as a bonus or penalty (your choice) to the d20 roll.

subclassFeature.name: Controlled Chaos
entries: You gain a modicum of control over the surges of your wild magic. Whenever you roll on the Wild {@action Magic} Surge table, you can roll twice and use either number.

subclassFeature.name: Tamed Surge
entries: Immediately after you cast a Sorcerer spell with a spell slot, you can create an effect of your choice from the {@table Wild Magic Surge} table instead of rolling on that table. You can choose any effect in the table except for the final row, and if the chosen effect involves a roll, you must make it.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

fluff.name: Warlock
entries: Arcane casters defined by their pact with a powerful patron. Warlocks use unique powers granted by their pact to cause damage, control the battlefield, and further their patrons aims on the material plane.

{@i Choose A or B:} (A) {@item Leather Armor}, {@item Sickle}, 2 {@item Dagger|Daggers}, {@item Arcane Focus} ({@item orb}), {@item Book} (occult lore), {@item Scholar's Pack}, and 15 GP; or (B) 100 GP

subclass.name: Great Old One Patron
subclassFeatures: Great Old One Patron|Warlock|Great Old One|3

classFeature.name: Eldritch Invocations
entries: You have unearthed Eldritch Invocations, pieces of forbidden knowledge that imbue you with an abiding magical ability or other lessons. You gain one invocation of your choice, such as Pact of the Tome. Invocations are described in the Eldritch Invocations.

entries.name: Prerequisites
entries: If an invocation has a prerequisite, you must meet it to learn that invocation. For example, if an invocation requires you to be a level 5+ Warlock, you can select the invocation once you reach Warlock level 5.

entries.name: Replacing and Gaining Invocations
entries: Whenever you gain a Warlock level, you can replace one of your invocations with another one for which you qualify. You can't replace an invocation if it's a prerequisite for another invocation that you have.
When you gain certain Warlock levels, you gain more invocations of your choice, as shown in the Invocations column of the Warlock Features table.
You can't pick the same invocation more than once unless its description says otherwise.

classFeature.name: Pact Magic
entries: Through occult ceremony, you have formed a pact with a mysterious entity to gain magical powers. The entity is a voice in the shadows—its identity unclear—but its boon to you is concrete: the ability to cast spells. The information below details how you use those rules with Warlock spells, which appear in the {@spells ?spell-class-filter=warlock|Warlock spell list}.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You know two Warlock cantrips of your choice. {@spell Eldritch Blast} and {@spell Friends} are recommended. Whenever you gain a Warlock level, you can replace one of your cantrips from this feature with another Warlock cantrip of your choice.
When you reach Warlock levels 4 and 10, you learn another Warlock cantrip of your choice, as shown in the Cantrips column of the Warlock Features table.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Warlock Features table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your Warlock spells of levels 1–5. The table also shows the level of those slots, all of which are the same level. You regain all expended Pact Magic spell slots when you finish a Short or Long Rest.
For example, when you're a level 5 Warlock, you have two level 3 spell slots. To cast the level 1 spell {@spell Witch Bolt}, you must spend one of those slots, and you cast it as a level 3 spell.

entries.name: Prepared Spells of Level 1+
entries: You prepare the list of level 1+ spells that are available for you to cast with this feature. To start, choose two level 1 Warlock spells. {@spell Armor of Agathys} and {@spell Hex} are recommended.

The number of spells on your list increases as you gain Warlock levels, as shown in the Spells column of the Warlock Features table. Whenever that number increases, choose additional Warlock spells until the number of spells on your list matches the number in the table. The chosen spells must be of a level no higher than what's shown in the table's Slot Level column for your level. When you reach level 6, for example, you learn a new Warlock spell, which can be of levels 1–3.

If another Warlock feature gives you spells that you always have prepared, those spells don't count against the number of spells you can prepare with this feature, but those spells otherwise count as Warlock spells for you.

entries.name: Changing Your Prepared Spells
entries: Whenever you gain a Warlock level, you can replace one spell on your list with another Warlock spell of an eligible level.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Charisma is the spellcasting ability for your Warlock spells.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use an {@item Arcane Focus} as a {@rule Spellcasting Focus} for your Warlock spells.

classFeature.name: Magical Cunning
entries: You can perform an esoteric rite for 1 minute. At the end of it, you regain expended Pact Magic spell slots but no more than a number equal to half your maximum (round up). Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

classFeature.name: Warlock Subclass
entries: You gain a Warlock subclass of your choice. A subclass is a specialization that grants you features at certain Warlock levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your subclass's features that are of your Warlock level or lower.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Warlock levels 8, 12, and 16.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Warlock subclass.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} Feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Contact Patron
entries: In the past, you usually contacted your patron through intermediaries. Now you can communicate directly; you always have the {@spell Contact Other Plane} spell prepared. With this feature, you can cast the spell without expending a spell slot to contact your patron, and you automatically succeed on the spell's saving throw.
Once you cast the spell with this feature, you can't do so in this way again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Warlock subclass.

classFeature.name: Mystic Arcanum
entries: Your patron grants you a magical secret called an arcanum. Choose one level 6 Warlock spell as this arcanum.
You can cast your arcanum spell once without expending a spell slot, and you must finish a {@rule Long Rest} before you can cast it in this way again.

As shown in the Warlock Features table, you gain another Warlock spell of your choice that can be cast in this way when you reach Warlock levels 13 (level 7 spell), 15 (level 8 spell), and 17 (level 9 spell). You regain all uses of your Mystic Arcanum when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.
Whenever you gain a Warlock level, you can replace one of your arcanum spells with another Warlock spell of the same level.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} Feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Mystic Arcanum
entries: You gain a level 7 Warlock Spell of your choice.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Warlock subclass.

classFeature.name: Mystic Arcanum
entries: You gain a level 8 Warlock Spell of your choice.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} Feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Mystic Arcanum
entries: You gain a level 9 Warlock Spell of your choice.

classFeature.name: Epic Boon
entries: You gain an {@epic-boon Epic Boon} or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify. {@epic-boon Boon of Fate} is recommended.

classFeature.name: Eldritch Master
entries: When you use your Magical Cunning feature, you regain all your expended Pact Magic spell slots.

subclassFeature.name: Archfey Patron
entries: {@i Bargain with Whimsical Fey}

Your pact draws on the power of the Feywild. When you choose this subclass, you might make a deal with an archfey, such as the Prince of Frost; the Queen of Air and {@rule Darkness}, ruler of the Gloaming Court; Titania of the Summer Court; or an ancient hag. Or you might call on a spectrum of Fey, weaving a web of favors and debts. Whoever they are, your patron is often inscrutable and whimsical.

subclassFeature.name: Archfey Spells
entries: The magic of your patron ensures you always have certain spells ready; when you reach a Warlock level specified in the Archfey Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Archfey Spells
rows: {@spell Calm Emotions}, {@spell Faerie Fire}, {@spell Misty Step}, {@spell Phantasmal Force}, {@spell Sleep}

subclassFeature.name: Steps of the Fey
entries: Your patron grants you the ability to move between the boundaries of the planes. You can cast {@spell Misty Step} without expending a spell slot a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.
In addition, whenever you cast that spell, you can choose one of the following additional effects.

entries.name: Refreshing Step
entries: Immediately after you teleport, you or one creature you can see within 10 feet of yourself gains 1d10 {@rule Temporary Hit Points}.

entries.name: Taunting Step
entries: Creatures within 5 feet of the space you left must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC or have {@rule Disadvantage} on attack rolls against creatures other than you until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Misty Escape
entries: You can cast {@spell Misty Step} as a {@rule Reaction} in response to taking damage.
In addition, the following effects are now among your Steps of the Fey options.

entries.name: Disappearing Step
entries: You have the {@condition Invisible} condition until the start of your next turn or until immediately after you make an attack roll, deal damage, or cast a spell.

entries.name: Dreadful Step
entries: Creatures within 5 feet of the space you left or the space you appear in (your choice) must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC or take {@damage 2d10} Psychic damage.

subclassFeature.name: Beguiling Defenses
entries: Your patron teaches you how to guard your mind and body. You are immune to the {@condition Charmed} condition.

In addition, immediately after a creature you can see hits you with an attack roll, you can take a {@rule Reaction} to reduce the damage you take by half (round down), and you can force the attacker to make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the attacker takes Psychic damage equal to the damage you take. Once you use this {@rule Reaction}, you can't use it again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest} unless you expend a Pact Magic spell slot (no action required) to restore your use of it.

subclassFeature.name: Bewitching Magic
entries: Your patron grants you the ability to weave your magic with teleportation. Immediately after you cast an Enchantment or Illusion spell using an action and a spell slot, you can cast {@spell Misty Step} as part of the same action and without expending a spell slot.

subclassFeature.name: Celestial Patron
entries: {@i Call on the Power of the Heavens}

Your pact draws on the Upper Planes, the realms of everlasting bliss. You might enter an agreement with an empyrean, a couatl, a sphinx, a unicorn, or another heavenly entity. Or you might call on numerous such beings as you pursue goals aligned with theirs. Your pact allows you to experience a hint of the holy light that illuminates the multiverse.

subclassFeature.name: Celestial Spells
entries: The magic of your patron ensures you always have certain spells ready; when you reach a Warlock level specified in the Celestial Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Celestial Spells
rows: {@spell Aid}, {@spell Cure Wounds}, {@spell Guiding Bolt}, {@spell Lesser Restoration}, {@spell Light}, {@spell Sacred Flame}
{@spell Guardian of Faith}, {@spell Wall of Fire}

subclassFeature.name: Healing Light
entries: You gain the ability to channel celestial energy to heal wounds. You have a pool of d6s to fuel this healing. The number of dice in the pool equals 1 plus your Warlock level.

As a {@rule Bonus Action}, you can heal yourself or one creature you can see within 60 feet of yourself, expending dice from the pool. The maximum number of dice you can expend at once equals your Charisma modifier (minimum of one die). Roll the dice you expend, and restore a number of Hit Points equal to the roll's total. Your pool regains all expended dice when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Radiant Soul
entries: Your link to your patron allows you to serve as a conduit for radiant energy. You have {@rule Resistance} to Radiant damage. Once per turn, when a spell you cast deals Radiant or Fire damage, you can add your Charisma modifier to that spell's damage against one of the spell's targets.

subclassFeature.name: Celestial Resilience
entries: You gain {@rule Temporary Hit Points} whenever you use your Magical Cunning feature or finish a Short or Long Rest. These {@rule Temporary Hit Points} equal your Warlock level plus your Charisma modifier. Additionally, choose up to five creatures you can see when you gain the points. Those creatures each gain {@rule Temporary Hit Points} equal to half your Warlock level plus your Charisma modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Searing Vengeance
entries: When you or an ally within 60 feet of you is about to make a {@rule Death Saving Throw}, you can unleash radiant energy to save the creature. The creature regains Hit Points equal to half its Hit Point maximum and can end the {@condition Prone} condition on itself. Each creature of your choice that is within 30 feet of the creature takes Radiant damage equal to 2d8 plus your Charisma modifier, and each has the {@condition Blinded} condition until the end of the current turn.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Fiend Patron
entries: {@i Make a Deal with the Lower Planes}

Your pact draws on the Lower Planes, the realms of perdition. You might forge a bargain with a demon lord such as Demogorgon or Orcus; an archdevil such as Asmodeus; or a pit fiend, balor, yugoloth, or night hag that is especially mighty. That patron's aims are evil—the corruption or destruction of all things, ultimately including you—and your path is defined by the extent to which you strive against those aims.

subclassFeature.name: Dark One's Blessing
entries: When you reduce an enemy to 0 Hit Points, you gain {@rule Temporary Hit Points} equal to your Charisma modifier plus your Warlock level (minimum of 1 {@rule Temporary Hit Points|Temporary Hit Point}). You also gain this benefit if someone else reduces an enemy within 10 feet of you to 0 Hit Points.

subclassFeature.name: Fiend Spells
entries: The magic of your patron ensures you always have certain spells ready; when you reach a Warlock level specified in the Fiend Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Fiend Spells
rows: {@spell Burning Hands}, {@spell Command}, {@spell Scorching Ray}, {@spell Suggestion}

subclassFeature.name: Dark One's Own Luck
entries: You can call on your fiendish patron to alter fate in your favor. When you make an ability check or a saving throw, you can use this feature to add 1d10 to your roll. You can do so after seeing the roll but before any of the roll's effects occur.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once), but you can use it no more than once per roll. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Fiendish Resilience
entries: Choose one damage type, other than Force, whenever you finish a Short or Long Rest. You have {@rule Resistance} to that damage type until you choose a different one with this feature.

subclassFeature.name: Hurl Through Hell
entries: Once per turn when you hit a creature with an attack roll, you can try to instantly transport the target through the Lower Planes. The target must succeed on a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC, or the target disappears and hurtles through a nightmare landscape. The target takes {@damage 8d10} Psychic damage if it isn't a Fiend, and it has the {@condition Incapacitated} condition until the end of your next turn, when it returns to the space it previously occupied or the nearest unoccupied space.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest} unless you expend a Pact Magic spell slot (no action required) to restore your use of it.

subclassFeature.name: Great Old One Patron
entries: {@i Unearth Forbidden Lore of Ineffable Beings}

When you choose this subclass, you might bind yourself to an unspeakable being from the Far Realm or an elder god—a being such as Tharizdun, the Chained God; Zargon, the Returner; Hadar, the Dark Hunger; or Great Cthulhu. Or you might invoke several entities without yoking yourself to one. The motives of these beings are incomprehensible, and the Great Old One might be indifferent to your existence. But the secrets you've learned nevertheless allow you to draw strange magic from it.

subclassFeature.name: Awakened Mind
entries: You can form a telepathic connection between your mind and the mind of another. As a {@rule Bonus Action}, choose one creature you can see within 30 feet of yourself. You and the chosen creature can communicate telepathically with each other while the two of you are within a number of miles of each other equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1 mile). To understand each other, you each must mentally use a language the other knows.
The telepathic connection lasts for a number of minutes equal to your Warlock level. It ends early if you use this feature to connect with a different creature.

subclassFeature.name: Great Old One Spells
entries: The magic of your patron ensures you always have certain spells ready; when you reach a Warlock level specified in the Great Old One Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Great Old One Spells
rows: {@spell Detect Thoughts}, {@spell Dissonant Whispers}, {@spell Phantasmal Force}, {@spell Tasha's Hideous Laughter}

subclassFeature.name: Psychic Spells
entries: When you cast a Warlock spell that deals damage, you can change its damage type to Psychic. In addition, when you cast a Warlock spell that is an Enchantment or {@rule Illusions|Illusion}, you can do so without Verbal or Somatic components.

subclassFeature.name: Clairvoyant Combatant
entries: When you form a telepathic bond with a creature using your Awakened Mind, you can force that creature to make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the creature has {@rule Disadvantage} on attack rolls against you, and you have {@rule Advantage} on attack rolls against that creature for the duration of the bond.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a Short or Long Rest unless you expend a Pact {@action Magic} spell slot (no action required) to restore your use of it.

subclassFeature.name: Eldritch Hex
entries: Your alien patron grants you a powerful curse. You always have the {@spell Hex} spell prepared. When you cast {@spell Hex} and choose an ability, the target also has {@rule Disadvantage} on saving throws of the chosen ability for the duration of the spell.

subclassFeature.name: Thought Shield
entries: Your thoughts can't be read by telepathy or other means unless you allow it. You also have {@rule Resistance} to Psychic damage, and whenever a creature deals Psychic damage to you, that creature takes the same amount of damage that you take.

subclassFeature.name: Create Thrall
entries: When you cast {@spell Summon Aberration}, you can modify it so that it doesn't require {@status Concentration}. If you do so, the spell's duration becomes 1 minute for that casting, and when summoned, the Aberration has a number of {@rule Temporary Hit Points} equal to your Warlock level plus your Charisma modifier.

In addition, the first time each turn the Aberration hits a creature under the effect of your {@spell Hex}, the Aberration deals extra Psychic damage to the target equal to the bonus damage of that spell.

fluff.name: Wizard
entries: Arcane casters defined by their powerful spells and devotion to studying magic. Wizard use their ingenuity and arcane power to create all manner of powerful spell effects.
{@i Choose A or B:} (A) 2 {@item Dagger|Daggers}, {@item Arcane Focus} ({@item Quarterstaff}), {@item Robe}, Spellbook, {@item Scholar's Pack}, and 5 GP; or (B) 55 GP

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: As a student of arcane magic, you have learned to cast spells. See {@book chapter 7|7} for the rules on spellcasting. The information below details how you use those rules with Wizard spells, which appear in the {@spells ?spell-class-filter=wizard|Wizard spell list}.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You know three Wizard cantrips of your choice. {@spell Light}, {@spell Mage Hand}, and one of {@spell Ray of Frost}, {@spell Fire Bolt}, or {@spell Spectral Grasp} are recommended. Whenever you finish a {@rule Long Rest}, you can replace one of your cantrips from this feature with another Wizard cantrip of your choice.
When you reach Wizard levels 4 and 10, you learn another Wizard cantrip of your choice, as shown in the Cantrips column of the Wizard Features table.

entries.name: Spellbook
entries: Your wizardly apprenticeship culminated in the creation of a unique book: your spellbook. It is a Tiny object that weighs 3 pounds, contains 100 pages, and can be read only by you or someone casting {@spell Identify}. You determine the book's appearance and materials, such as a gilt-edged tome or a collection of vellum bound with twine.

The book contains the level 1+ spells you know. It starts with six level 1 Wizard spells of your choice. {@spell Detect Magic}, {@spell Feather Fall}, {@spell Mage Armor}, {@spell Magic Missile}, {@spell Sleep}, and {@spell Thunderwave} are recommended.

Whenever you gain a Wizard level after 1, add two Wizard spells of your choice to your spellbook. Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots, as shown in the Wizard Features table. The spells are the culmination of arcane research you do regularly.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Wizard Features table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your level 1+ spells. You regain all expended slots when you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

entries.name: Prepared Spells of Level 1+
entries: You prepare the list of level 1+ spells that are available for you to cast with this feature. To do so, choose four spells from your spellbook. The chosen spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

The number of spells on your list increases as you gain Wizard levels, as shown in the Spells column of the Wizard Features table. Whenever that number increases, choose additional Wizard spells until the number of spells on your list matches the number in the table. The chosen spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For example, if you're a level 3 Wizard, your list of prepared spells can include six spells of levels 1 and 2 in any combination, chosen from your spellbook.

If another Wizard feature gives you spells that you always have prepared, those spells don't count against the number of spells you can prepare with this feature, but those spells otherwise count as Wizard spells for you.

entries.name: Changing Your Prepared Spells
entries: Whenever you finish a {@rule Long Rest}, you can change your list of prepared spells, replacing any of the spells there with spells from your spellbook.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your Wizard spells.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use an {@item Arcane Focus} or your spellbook as a {@rule Spellcasting Focus} for your Wizard spells.

entries.name: Expanding and Replacing a Spellbook
entries: The spells you add to your spellbook as you gain levels reflect your ongoing magical research, but you might find other spells during your adventures that you can add to the book. You could discover a Wizard spell on a {@item Spell Scroll}, for example, and then copy it into your spellbook.

entries.name: Copying a Spell into the Book
entries: When you find a level 1+ Wizard spell, you can copy it into your spellbook if it's of a level you can prepare and if you have time to copy it. For each level of the spell, the transcription takes 2 hours and costs 50 GP. Afterward you can prepare the spell like the other spells in your spellbook.

entries.name: Copying the Book
entries: You can copy a spell from your spellbook into another book. This is like copying a new spell into your spellbook but faster, since you already know how to cast the spell. You need spend only 1 hour and 10 GP for each level of the copied spell.

If you lose your spellbook, you can use the same procedure to transcribe the Wizard spells that you have prepared into a new spellbook. Filling out the remainder of the new book requires you to find new spells to do so. For this reason, many wizards keep a backup spellbook.

classFeature.name: Ritual Adept
entries: You can cast any spell as a {@rule Ritual} if that spell has the {@rule Ritual} tag and the spell is in your spellbook. You needn't have the spell prepared, but you must read from the book to cast a spell in this way.

classFeature.name: Arcane Recovery
entries: You can regain some of your magical energy by studying your spellbook. When you finish a {@rule Short Rest}, you can choose expended spell slots to recover. The spell slots can have a combined level equal to no more than half your Wizard level (round up), and none of the slots can be level 6 or higher. For example, if you're a level 4 Wizard, you can recover up to two levels' worth of spell slots, regaining either one level 2 spell slot or two level 1 spell slots.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

classFeature.name: Scholar
entries: While studying magic, you also specialized in another field of study. Choose one of the following skills in which you have proficiency: {@skill Arcana}, {@skill History}, {@skill Investigation}, {@skill Medicine}, {@skill Nature}, or {@skill Religion}. You have {@rule Expertise} in the chosen skill.

classFeature.name: Wizard Subclass
