entries: You gain a Wizard subclass of your choice. A subclass is a specialization that grants you features at certain Wizard levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your subclass's features that are of your Wizard level or lower.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You gain the {@feat Ability Score Improvement} feat or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify. You gain this feature again at Wizard levels 8, 12, and 16.

classFeature.name: Memorize Spell
entries: Whenever you finish a {@rule Short Rest}, you can study your spellbook and replace one of the level 1+ Wizard spells you have prepared for your Spellcasting feature with another level 1+ spell from the book.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Wizard Subclass.

classFeature.name: Spell Mastery
entries: You have achieved such mastery over certain spells that you can cast them at will. Choose a level 1 and a level 2 spell in your spellbook that have a casting time of an action. You always have those spells prepared, and you can cast them at their lowest level without expending a spell slot. To cast either spell at a higher level, you must expend a spell slot.

classFeature.name: Epic Boon
entries: You gain an {@epic-boon Epic Boon} or another {@feat feat} of your choice for which you qualify. {@epic-boon Boon of Spell Recall} is recommended.

classFeature.name: Signature Spells
entries: Choose two level 3 spells in your spellbook as your signature spells. You always have these spells prepared, and you can cast each of them once at level 3 without expending a spell slot. When you do so, you can't cast them in this way again until you finish a Short or Long Rest. To cast either spell at a higher level, you must expend a spell slot.ended.

subclassFeature.name: Abjurer
entries: {@i Shield Companions and Banish Foes}

Your study of magic is focused on spells that block, banish, or protect—ending harmful effects, banishing evil influences, and protecting the weak. Abjurers are sought when baleful spirits require exorcism, when locations must be guarded against magical spying, and when portals to other planes of existence must be closed. Adventuring parties value Abjurers for the protection they provide against a variety of hostile magic and other attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Abjuration Savant
entries: Choose two Wizard spells from the Abjuration school, each of which must be no higher than level 2, and add them to your spellbook for free.

In addition, whenever you gain access to a new level of spell slots in this class, you can add one Wizard spell from the Abjuration school to your spellbook for free. The chosen spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Ward
entries: You can weave magic around yourself for protection. When you cast an Abjuration spell with a spell slot, you can simultaneously use a strand of the spell's magic to create a magical ward on yourself that lasts until you finish a {@rule Long Rest}. The ward has a {@rule Hit Points|Hit Point} maximum equal to twice your Wizard level plus your Intelligence modifier. Whenever you take damage, the ward takes the damage instead, and if you have any Resistances or Vulnerabilities, apply them before reducing the ward's Hit Points. If the damage reduces the ward to 0 Hit Points, you take any remaining damage. While the ward has 0 Hit Points, it can't absorb damage, but its magic remains.

Whenever you cast an Abjuration spell with a spell slot, the ward regains a number of Hit Points equal to twice the level of the spell slot. Alternatively, as a {@rule Bonus Action}, you can expend a spell slot, and the ward regains a number of Hit Points equal to twice the level of the spell slot expended.
Once you create the ward, you can't create it again until you finish a {@rule Long Rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Projected Ward
entries: When a creature that you can see within 30 feet of yourself takes damage, you can take a {@rule Reaction} to cause your Arcane Ward to absorb that damage. If this damage reduces the ward to 0 Hit Points, the warded creature takes any remaining damage. If that creature has any Resistances or Vulnerabilities, apply them before reducing the ward's Hit Points.

subclassFeature.name: Spell Breaker
entries: You always have the {@spell Counterspell} and {@spell Dispel Magic} spells prepared. In addition, you can cast {@spell Dispel Magic} as a {@rule Bonus Action}, and you can add your {@rule Proficiency} Bonus to its ability check.
When you cast either spell with a spell slot, that slot isn't expended if the spell fails to stop a spell.

subclassFeature.name: Spell Resistance
entries: You have {@rule Advantage} on saving throws against spells, and you have {@rule Resistance} to the damage of spells.

subclassFeature.name: Diviner
entries: {@i Learn the Secrets of the Multiverse}

The counsel of a Diviner is sought by those who want a clearer understanding of the past, present, and future. As a Diviner, you strive to part the veils of space, time, and consciousness. You work to master spells of discernment, remote viewing, supernatural knowledge, and foresight.

subclassFeature.name: Divination Savant
entries: Choose two Wizard spells from the Divination school, each of which must be no higher than level 2, and add them to your spellbook for free.

In addition, whenever you gain access to a new level of spell slots in this class, you can add one Wizard spell from the Divination school to your spellbook for free. The chosen spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

subclassFeature.name: Portent
entries: Glimpses of the future begin to press on your awareness. Whenever you finish a {@rule Long Rest}, roll two d20s and record the numbers rolled. You can replace any {@rule D20 Test} made by you or a creature that you can see with one of these foretelling rolls. You must choose to do so before the roll, and you can replace a roll in this way only once per turn.
Each foretelling roll can be used only once. When you finish a {@rule Long Rest}, you lose any unused foretelling rolls.

subclassFeature.name: Expert Divination
entries: Casting Divination spells comes so easily to you that it expends only a fraction of your spellcasting efforts. When you cast a Divination spell using a level 2+ spell slot, you regain one expended spell slot. The slot you regain must be of a level lower than the slot you expended and can't be higher than level 5.

subclassFeature.name: The Third Eye
entries: You can increase your powers of perception. As a {@rule Bonus Action}, choose one of the following benefits, which lasts until you start a Short or Long Rest. You can't use this feature again until you finish a Short or Long Rest.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You gain {@sense Darkvision} with a range of 120 feet.

entries.name: Greater Comprehension
entries: You can read any language.

entries.name: See Invisibility
entries: You can cast {@spell See Invisibility} without expending a spell slot.

subclassFeature.name: Greater Portent
entries: The visions in your dreams intensify and paint a more accurate picture in your mind of what is to come. Roll three d20s for your Portent feature rather than two.

subclassFeature.name: Evoker
entries: {@i Create Explosive Elemental Effects}

Your studies focus on magic that creates powerful elemental effects such as bitter cold, searing flame, rolling thunder, crackling lightning, and burning acid. Some Evokers find employment in military forces, serving as artillery to blast armies from afar. Others use their power to protect others, while some seek their own gain.

subclassFeature.name: Evocation Savant
entries: Choose two Wizard spells from the Evocation school, each of which must be no higher than level 2, and add them to your spellbook for free.

In addition, whenever you gain access to a new level of spell slots in this class, you can add one Wizard spell from the Evocation school to your spellbook for free. The chosen spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

subclassFeature.name: Potent Cantrip
entries: Your damaging cantrips affect even creatures that avoid the brunt of the effect. When you cast a cantrip at a creature and you miss with the attack roll or the target succeeds on a saving throw against the cantrip, the target takes half the cantrip's damage (if any) but suffers no additional effect from the cantrip.

subclassFeature.name: Sculpt Spells
entries: You can create pockets of relative safety within the effects of your evocations. When you cast an Evocation spell that affects other creatures that you can see, you can choose a number of them equal to 1 plus the spell's level. The chosen creatures automatically succeed on their saving throws against the spell, and they take no damage if they would normally take half damage on a successful save.

subclassFeature.name: Empowered Evocation
entries: Whenever you cast a Wizard spell from the Evocation school, you can add your Intelligence modifier to one damage roll of that spell.

subclassFeature.name: Overchannel
entries: You can increase the power of your spells. When you cast a Wizard spell with a spell slot of levels 1–5 that deals damage, you can deal maximum damage with that spell on the turn you cast it.

The first time you do so, you suffer no adverse effect. If you use this feature again before you finish a {@rule Long Rest}, you take {@damage 2d12} Necrotic damage for each level of the spell slot immediately after you cast it. This damage ignores {@rule Resistance} and {@rule Immunity}.
Each time you use this feature again before finishing a {@rule Long Rest}, the Necrotic damage per spell level increases by 1d12.

subclassFeature.name: Illusionist
entries: {@i Weave Subtle Spells of Deception}
You specialize in magic that dazzles the senses and tricks the mind, and the illusions you craft make the impossible seem real.

subclassFeature.name: Illusion Savant
entries: Choose two Wizard spells from the Illusion school, each of which must be no higher than level 2, and add them to your spellbook for free.

In addition, whenever you gain access to a new level of spell slots in this class, you can add one Wizard spell from the Illusion school to your spellbook for free. The chosen spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Illusions
entries: You can cast Illusion spells without providing Verbal components, and if an Illusion spell you cast has a range of 10+ feet, the range increases by 60 feet.

You also know the {@spell Minor Illusion} cantrip. If you already know it, you learn a different Wizard cantrip of your choice. The cantrip doesn't count against your number of cantrips known. You can create both a sound and an image with a single casting of {@spell Minor Illusion}, and you can cast it as a {@rule Bonus Action}.

subclassFeature.name: Phantasmal Creatures
entries: You always have the {@spell Summon Beast} and {@spell Summon Fey} spells prepared. Whenever you cast either spell, you can change its school to Illusion, which causes the summoned creature to appear spectral. You can cast the Illusion version of each spell without expending a spell slot, but casting it without a slot halves the creature's Hit Points. Once you cast either spell without a spell slot, you must finish a {@rule Long Rest} before you can cast the spell in that way again.

subclassFeature.name: Illusory Self
entries: When a creature hits you with an attack roll, you can take a {@rule Reaction} to interpose an illusory duplicate of yourself between the attacker and yourself. The attack automatically misses you, then the illusion dissipates.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a Short or Long Rest. You can also restore your use of it by expending a level 2+ spell slot (no action required).

subclassFeature.name: Illusory Reality
entries: You have learned to weave shadow magic into your illusions to give them a semi-reality. When you cast an Illusion spell with a spell slot, you can choose one inanimate, nonmagical object that is part of the illusion and make that object real. You can do this on your turn as a {@rule Bonus Action} while the spell is ongoing. The object remains real for 1 minute, during which it can't deal damage or give any conditions. For example, you can create an illusion of a bridge over a chasm and then make it real and cross it.
